in v3 data types, the address is *postal address* only, though it nicely also has PHYS/PST codes.

In FHIR, there's a location resource for physical location, which does have an address, and which is how the requirement should be dealt with. Otherwise, I very much doubt that PHYS/PST is 80% for address
The question came about with respect to the Location resource actually.  Locations can also have mailing addresses and it wasn't clear how to represent this.

I have changed ProfileGenerator.java to split Resource(A|B|C) up into several TypeRefs, each with type="ResourceReference" and profile=#A. This led to the InstanceValidator triggering a validation warning (multiple types?). After I changed that, the ProfileValidator now gives an error, because when filling out a differential profile (in this case the diagnosticreport lipids example), these will result in several repeats of the TypeRef node (with type=ResourceReference) without the differing profiles. In other words, the specified profile on the base resource profile doesn't yet get correctly filled out. I tried to fix this in ProfileValidator's filloutElementDefn(ElementDefn n, ElementComponent e), but it doesn't seem to work.
now all fixed up. Marking as applied

It's not really true for documents either.  Composition.text may well include some summary information about the author, custodian, etc. if this is considered important for human understanding of the document.  (It won't be rendered by the rendering algorithm for displaying a document for authentication.)  In List, we explicitly say that the List SHALL include summary information about the resources referenced in the List (often in a table form).  Otherwise, when you have a List referenced in a Composition.section, the content of the list wouldn't be rendered in the Document display.  We have some work to do in making the rules consistent or at least making very clear what the exceptions are and why they exist.  More discussion for core team required.

Woody/Bill 11/0/0

Agree that a list resource narrative includes elements of the item content (data or narrative) in the list. We don't say that this should be true about documents either. Maybe the language there needs some clarification

I'd suggest the following as general documentation (in "narrative.html"): Narrative for a resource should include summary information about referenced resources as necessary for a consumer of the resource to be able to understand the key essential information about a resource without retrieving additional resources.  For example, the narrative for a MedicationPrescription might include summary information about the referenced patient, prescriber and medication.  Some resources (e.g. List, Composition) may provide specific rules about what content must (or must not) be included in the resource narrative.  Consideration should be given to the fact that referenced resources may be updated without updating referencing resources, so the proportion of content of a referenced resource included in a referencing resource should be limited.

what else other than supercedes? possible: defined for use from... but that creates circular references...

Lloyd: Suggest adding an element of "replaces" 0..1 and "compliesWith" 0..*.  Also add corresponding search criteria.  Not happy with a "typed" association.

Would it be better to point from retired profile to replacing profile or vice versa.  Should there be constraints on when "superceded" can be present?  E.g. Can only have if status=retired?  Also would need to define exactly what "supercedes" means.

Push this back for further definition.  Grahame/Ewout - any more comments

- it would be wrong to point from retired to replacing. That violates our general rule about pointing backwards in time not forwards

- courtesy of the rework to profile, we now have 'base"- how is that different from "complies with"

- we don't have supercedes in any of the other conformance layer resources

Well, the retired has to be updated to change the status to be retired.  In doing so, pointing to what you're replacing it with seems reasonable.  And it's a whole lot more useful that way.

Base is 0..1.  Complies with would be 0..*

Agree that this isn't necessariliy specific to Profile.  Could apply to ValueSet and possibly Conformance.  Not sure it would make sense elsewhere.

but you can't assume that you can chase down every copy of a profile to update it to point forwards. 

You still haven't defined the difference between based and complies. I don't understand why you'd record complies - it seems very fragile

Based says "here's the starting point against which deltas are applied".  Complies says "this compile profile complies with this other profile too".  There can only be one base.  There can be 0..* additional complies.

Any copy of a profile you don't chase down is going to continue to have a status of "active" instead of "retired".  Really, all you should need to do is update the source of truth copy (the one where id = identifier).  Everyone else is responsible for keeping their copy up-to-date with that copy (if they care about changes like retirement/replacement/etc. at all).
I don't know of a use case for Complies. Does it exist anywhere else in any HL7 , dicom, or IHE spec? I don't recognise the concept from any real spec.

Referral is in scope for this release.  While referrals are orders for care, this is frequently the mechanism used for ordering procedures - you're referred to a surgeon or to an occupational therapist or physio therapist or psychologist or whatever.  I haven't typically seen orders for "procedures" except as encompassed in a referral. Once Referral exists, do you think we'll have a need for another resource?  (And if so, what would be the guidance on when to use one vs. the other?)

What about a "planned" procedure? 

A dermatologist sees a patient and performs an examination and plan to perform a biopsy (a planned procedure).If he will perform the procedure himself neither an "order" nor a "referral" will be created. 

Will a "plan" resource be needed?

I'm looking for something that is planned - that may or may not happen - has not been ordered nor need to be referred for someone else to do.
The expectation is that a new resource called ProcedureRequest or ProcedureOrder will be created.  It will likely include an ability to allow it to represent requests.
ProcedureRequest is defined now.

Proposal to add following codes to 1.14.2.1.118  Value Set for codes in http://hl7.org/fhir/observation-reliability

Presumptive  An initial diagnostic test result.  Confirmatory tests are required to confirm the analysis.

Confirmed  A results which confirms whether or not an initial diagnostic test result is correct.

Changed wording to ...
Presumptive:  An diagnostic test result where further testing would be required for a definitive result.

Confirmed:  A results which confirms whether or not an initial diagnostic test result is correct.

There are questions about observation.reliability as its current definition does not map to OBX.8 or OBX.9.  OBX-8 maps to Interpretation.  OBX-9 does not fit well as it is a probability.  Then we can determine whether reliability is in the 80/20 - we don't believe so, but are open.  Then we can determine where presumptive and confimed fit in.
Need to decide whether this a required field.  Will be discussed at the Sept WGM, Wednesday Q3.

Reliability isn't actually core. It's included on other grounds - that it is core for devices, that is actually applicable for all observations, even if its not core, that when it's present, it's a modifier that can't be ignored - for which standard recommendation is that it be 1..* since what does it mean if it's not present? the fact that we have so much observational data of unknown reliability is actually rather sobering. But since it is very often unknown, it really can't continue to be 1..1, and should be changed to 0..1. I still believe that the fact is is a modifier and core in some of the sub-domains justifies it's inclusion

RE  question if this is in scope of .reliability   to add to next week's discussion.

(From Ewout): "Yes, we do not have Reference(any) on all elements, since this would require all systems implementing FHIR to be able to track these references. So, we try to limit the references to references that most systems are expected to track already. It's conceivable we've missed some useful possibilities (Group?), can you indicate what resources you'd like to refer to in subject?"

(Put discussion in the follow-up section, not the "agreed change" section :>)

I see Patient being in the 80%.  I see RelatedPerson as being pretty unlikely.  If you're doing a family history, odds are that all relatives will be tracked as part of a single questionnaire - which will still be a subject of Patient.  I expect that Medication, Device, Organization, Location and possibly Practitioner could all see use.  My suggestion would be to either add those or drop RelatedPerson.  (And note that other subjects can be noted via extension.)

Consensus from Connectathon was to remove RelatedPerson (it was added for reasons that don't actually turn out to be true).  Also add a note that Questionnaires *can* be about other subjects (handled as extensions) and open issue about differentiating subject & recordTarget (e.g. may have a questionnaire that's about a device that's also patient-specific and thus should live on their record)

I would say that "missed" and "rescheduled" are both sub-types of "cancelled".  So these could be handled by sending "cancelled" and then using an extension to capture the further differentiation.  That doesn't mean that adding the new codes would be inappropriate (if we deem them within the 80%).  We would need to make very clear what the boundaries were though so that there was no overlap between the codes.  We'd probably have to go hierarchical as not all systems would necessarily distinguish.

Assume the current value list as implemented is flat:  [ planned | in progress | onleave | finished | cancelled ]

Could represent a hierarchical list with sub-types with slash (/) or semi-colon (;) without using an extension to the status element.

e.g. cancelled/missed, cancelled/rescheduled, etc.

Value sets in FHIR don't have to be flat.  We can define (and publish) them as hierarchical when necessary.  As a rule, reflecting the hierarchy in the display names is frowned upon.  It tends to make them long.  However, we'll look to the patient administration work group to suggest the most appropriate (least likely to be confused) names.
~~The WG considers "missed" and "rescheduled" to be status' more appropriate for appointments rather than for encounter. These status' should be checked in the appointment resource status.
I did not submit this. Handing back to last submitter.

I concur that canceled can cover 'missed' status (aka noshow) given the Appointment.status codes: { pending | booked | arrived | fulfilled | cancelled | noshow }

'rescheduled' case could be represented as canceled but not the best mapping.

There is undesired overlap and dependency between Encounter.status and Appointment.status.

If have an Appointment where status=booked or pending then the encounter has not started so presumably does not yet exist as any record.

If Encounter.status=planned then Encounter.Fulfills.status in { arrived | fulfilled | cancelled | noshow } is not valid.

Until Appointment.status=arrived would any EHR actually create an encounter associated with a future appointment with status=planned ? Does this meet the 80% rule?

When Appointment.status=cancelled  | noshow would an encounter that never occurred be recorded ??

It's very common for Encounter to exist before the appointment is deemed fulfilled.  If the hospital is doing "billable" things - prepping the room, doing pre-admit work, etc., that'll be tracked as an actve encounter well before the patient is supposed to actually show up for surgery.

For each value of Appointment.status there is an implied subset of Encounter.status codes that makes sense. Other combinations may not be valid. The workflow and possible combinations are not clearly documented.

Appointment.status= pending | booked | arrived | fulfilled | cancelled | noshow
Encounter.status= planned | arrived | in progress | onleave | finished | cancelled

Appointment.status        Encounter.status

         pending                 planned | onleave
         booked                  planned
         arrived                   arrived | in progress
         fulfilled                   arrived | in progress | finished | onleave | cancelled
         cancelled               cancelled
         noshow                  cancelled

From Encounter documentation: "Once this [Appointment] process is completed and the appointment is about to start, then the appointment will be marked as fulfilled, and linked to the newly created encounter".

If you'd like to propose documenting recommended relationships, I'd add this as a separate proposal (this one's already been rejected).  That said, keep in mind that the encounters and appointments are separate objects that may be maintained by separate systems.  Clear alignment won't always exist, so all we can suggest is "intention".

That said, a few comments on your proposed linkage:

I' don't think "pending" could correspond to "onleave".  onleave implies that the encounter has initiated.  Also, there might not be an encounter at all for significant periods within the appointment's lifecycle.

this needs to be revisited in the light of other changes. There is a requirement to return a meta with a 200. I think the way this should be done is:

- if the client submits a delete with no body - server returns a 204 with no body

- if the client submits a delete with a meta for the body - the server returns a 200 ok with an updated meta

This is an odd corner case, but there are reasons to want to get the updated meta. on ther other hand, we could just say that if you really want it, then you just get it using a _meta operation

Lots of discussion about this on internet forums. However, as I have stated there are problems with support for DELETE with bodies. I know of problems in .NET WebApi2, and apparently this is true for some android support libraries too. Please don't do it.

When deleting:

401 - if not authorized

200 - this action deleted and optionally with OperationOutcome in body

204 - this action deleted and no body

404 - resource doesn't exist now or ever

409 - conflict (couldn't delete) may contain a body OperationOutcome

410 - existed before but already gone

(Idempotent does not apply to return code)

What happens to data (meta) in sent in the body on a Delete is undefined, perhaps you'd like to perform an Update on meta. Delete removes the content at the endpoint.

Feedback from connectathon: Should have title, code and identifier.  The title is the human-readable name for the group (same as group.header).  The code identifies the meaning for the group (e.g. LOINC code).  The identifier is how a question or group in the QuestionnaireAnswer gets tied to the Questionnaire Definition.  Need all 3 on group, need code & id on question

What circular references?  xhtml1-strict only imports xml.xsd which doesn't importa anything.

There *is* a circular reference between fhir-all, the individual resources and fhir-base, however this problem is addressed by the inclusion of fhir-single.xsd.  Are you encountering code-generation issue with fhir-single.xsd?  If so, please be explicit about what problem you're encountering.  If not, then my leaning would be consider this issue closed.

I had been using fhir-atom-single.xsd.  Using fhir-single.xsd to generate classes with unedited xhtml1-strict.xsd still fails with circular reference.  fhir-single.xsd still references xhtml1-strict.xsd.  I am using xsd2code addin from CodePlex with Visual Studio 2013 and am also using xsd.exe, and I still see the same circular reference error.  As long as an unedited xhtml1-strict.xsd is part of the set,  .Net tools cannot generate classes from these files:

Microsoft (R) Xml Schemas/DataTypes support utility
[Microsoft (R) .NET Framework, Version 4.0.30319.33440]
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
Error: Error generating classes for schema 'fhir-single_tombstone_opensearch_ope
nsearchscore_xmldsig-core-schema_xhtml1-strict_xml'.
  - Group 'block' from targetNamespace='http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml' has invali
d definition: Circular group reference.
Does it tell you what the circular reference is that it doesn't like?  Because in tracing the imports, I can't see one . . .

In the output, you can see it complains about 'block'. Fix that one and there are others. As far as I can tell, this schema is there to support embedding HTML in the XML. That is kind of questionable, since it will mess up the xml parsers used to deserialize. I can see why you might want to do this, but it causes real issues. Take a look at the .Net implementation on the website. You can see the developer removed the div element from his classes.

Now consider a developer accepts a feed from system 1, where they wrote custom serializers to handle this. They import into system 2, where they removed the tag because they did not want to handle this. The HTML gets dropped. Why support this in the first place if it causes trouble.

If the fhir team decides <div> is a good idea, we still need to be able to create classes with "out-of the-box" tools from these schemas. That means fixing the schema.  However, I still think it is a bad idea unless someone can tell me why it is.

I would attach the the fix I worked out,  if I could attach files. Can't see how to do that. I linked it https://onedrive.live.com/redir?resid=DC00B7D9CE3B0F3E!19326&authkey=!AFOBYgQTfVIkYrk&ithint=file%2c.xsd
Please list the parsers where you think that their limitations would justify removing functionality from the specification

XML parsers are going to see HTML elements and think they are XML. If there are no classes to contain the values, the parser will either ignore them - dropping the data or choke.

One option to fixing this requires fixing xhtml1-strict.xsd. As long as the HTML does not violate the fixes everybody is happy. One change I had to make was:

  <xs:complexType name="form.content">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>
      form uses "Block" excluding form
      </xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:choice minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded">
      <!--<xs:group ref="block"/>-->
      <!--<xs:group ref="misc"/>-->
    </xs:choice>
  </xs:complexType>

But changes like thisw are hard, and different developers may do a different change. I think the fix should be in the original schema to prevent this fragmentation.

Attached is a typical link explaining the problem better than I can: http://www.biglist.com/lists/xsl-list/archives/200008/msg00144.html The suggested fix here is to use CDATA to hold the HTML. I think this approach would be acceptable since you can contain the data without all the other problems that go with it when you try to make it XML.

Here is another: http://evolt.org/node/27855/. The fix is inappropriate here as comments are lost during serialization.

The point is this is concept people are strugling with because HTML is not XML. If this is really required, I would vote for the CDATA approach. It is not perfect, but will allow the desired effect of embedding non xml in the xml.

In my opinion, the great opportunity of fhir is one of interoperability across languages and protocols. To acheive this, the generation of classes needs to be simple and foolproof. "Out-of-the-box" tools used for generating classes from other xsd's and serializing/deserializing these classes is a must have. Having custom classes created and precompiled for you is great, until you are using a new language, or database or the classes need to be extended.

xhtml is proper xml, and this is perfectly valid xml that all xml parsers can handle just fine. 

Your problem is with schema based code generation tools that cannot generate code for xhtml correctly. Effectively, you want the xhtml moved out of the object model into a different layer - exactly what we do in the json. And frankly, Ewout and I who maintain the reference implementations would much rather do that. It's the object orientated engineer's natural view of the world. 

But the world is not composed only of object orientated engineers - there are also many many xml centric people, who object strenuously to moving the xhtml out of the xml and carrying it escaped or cdataed or whatever, because it makes xml handling harder. You can see an earlier comment of mine from our argument about this here: http://www.healthintersections.com.au/?p=470. This is why json will naturally become the preferred data exchange in the long term. 

I'm not sure that we can "fix" the xhtml schema - it's not ours, and I'd have to review the copyright etc. I'd like generation of classes from the schemas to be simple and foolproof, and we worked really hard to ensure that the fhir schemas are, The fact that the problems are in the external schemas, that are ubiquitious - well, it's both reassuring and painful. But surely we are the only ones with this problem?

17-Sept 2014: Flattened and simplified the schemas to aid in code generation, but no change to the existing format of resources (this was done as part of the schema changes made to ensure that the schema only allowed the approved parts of XHTML). Grahame/Paul 6-0-0

Ewout,

if Fhir is defined in a number of spreadsheets, and the schemas are artifacts, then there is a problem, in my opinion. The schemas are what all major tools can uniformly handle and use for conformance checking. How are you supposed to accept data from one system that has it's own schema into a system with another schema ? Joe, schemas are a problem - a schema for validation is a very different thing from a schema for code generation. I've thought about publishing 2 lots of schemas for this reason. It's not our issue - it's how schemas are. And schemas are very dumb, so they're not a great place to implement from. However many people will, because that's what the tools are for, so we care about them.

But it seems that you are actually talking about the FHIR generator that generates the c# reference implementation, not the schema at all?

I guess we just disagree. Its Ok.

I see a schema as a great starting point to make classes. The classes allows population of the datastructure in a somewhat controlled manner ensuring a certain tree, with certain datatypes and names to be created - it's not 100% but it is mostly there. From the tree of classes, I can serialize to XML. I can then validate the XML against the original xsd to make sure the data conforms to the schema. I can even use schematron to make sure the values really comply, - such as a start date is before an end date. It seems so simple and obvious to me. The key to this world are schemas that do not have fancy stuff in them.

Two lots of schemas seem difficult to me. The real issues I see are few and fixable.

1 - Move HTML to CDATA.
2 - Drop use of <any> where it is not really needed. ObjectType and TextType properties can be defined as something else.
3 - Rename value to val. This is probalby a nuanced bug in .Net,  but why not rename the field.
4 - Rename var to something (var is a c# keyword and creates IDE problems, I renamed it to Var). This is just a C# issue, but it is important.
5 - Reconsider the mixed datatypes that end up defining "object" types. ie, deceasedX in Patient object. Why not allow both fields, instead of using a choice element.
6 - Reconsider the use of mixed datatypes in lists like FeedType.Items (defined as a list of different items) Why not define lists of each item desired.

These are C# issues. I assume JAVA has it's own - but they should be addressed as well. From my examination of the schemas, it seems the same goals can be acheived, just by using some slight naming changes or different appraoches.

ok, thanks for clarifying. I tend to ignore the xhtml schema when looking through the schemas, because well, surely the tools work with such a ubiquitious schema. Apparently not... 

So, let's just explore #5. Here the schema says: 

          <xs:choice minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="1" >
            <xs:annotation>
              <xs:documentation>...</xs:documentation>
            </xs:annotation>
            <xs:element name="deceasedBoolean" type="boolean"/>
            <xs:element name="deceasedAge" type="Age"/>
            <xs:element name="deceasedRange" type="Range"/>
            <xs:element name="deceasedDate" type="date"/>
            <xs:element name="deceasedString" type="string"/>
          </xs:choice>

This is clear, and serves validation. We could define this some other way - simpler, with less rules, which would serve the code generation, but reduce validation. This is an example of the trade-off between generation and validation. 

As for why not allow more than one of these - what would it mean to have more than one, and have them disagree? that generates much more work, at a later more costly stage in the development cycle. So after much discussion, we elected to only have one marker, with a variety of types. That xsd.exe chooses to convert this to a polymorphic object, well, that's their choice based on their own extensive argument (I guess).

I don't think there's an easier way here - anything we do is a compromise somehow.

I'll research the issues with atom and xhtml schema more - but surely we're not the only ones to use these schemas? You can't tell me that no one else wants to use these schemas with portable class libraries?
I think you should ask about #3 on stackoverflow - it's hard to believe that some thing so simple and ubiquitious as a "value" attribute doesn't work right

It has been a while since I last looked at this, but to start this was the most egregios issue related to class generation and serialization:

1: Using separate properties for choice elements (this happens min many locations):

Suggested Class Generation Schema

             (Include annotiation in schema to indicate a choice will be enforced)

             <xs:element name="deceasedBoolean" type="boolean"/>
             <xs:element name="deceasedAge" type="Age"/>
             <xs:element name="deceasedRange" type="Range"/>
             <xs:element name="deceasedDate" type="date"/>
             <xs:element name="deceasedString" type="string"/>

Validatation Schema

<xs:choice minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="1" >
             <xs:annotation>
               <xs:documentation>...</xs:documentation>
             </xs:annotation>
             <xs:element name="deceasedBoolean" type="boolean"/>
             <xs:element name="deceasedAge" type="Age"/>
             <xs:element name="deceasedRange" type="Range"/>
             <xs:element name="deceasedDate" type="date"/>
             <xs:element name="deceasedString" type="string"/>
</xs:choice>

 

3: Types that generate XmlNode properties

These are examples that force XmlNode arrays to be created. XMLNode is incompatible with PCL's in .Net

Validatation Schema

<element name="DigestMethod" type="ds:DigestMethodType"/>
  <complexType name="DigestMethodType" mixed="true">
    <sequence>
    <any namespace="##other" processContents="lax" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
    </sequence>
    <attribute name="Algorithm" type="anyURI" use="required"/>
  </complexType>

<element name="CanonicalizationMethod" type="ds:CanonicalizationMethodType"/>
  <complexType name="CanonicalizationMethodType" mixed="true">
    <sequence>
      <any namespace="##any" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
      <!-- (0,unbounded) elements from (1,1) namespace -->
    </sequence>
    <attribute name="Algorithm" type="anyURI" use="required"/>
  </complexType>
 

Not really sure what the solution is here - not even sure if the types are used and needed - if not they could be stripped from the schema.

I'd like to add my +1 to switching Patient.gender to Code from CodeableConcept. I've now twice explained FHIR to a group of developers, and the Patient resource is always where I start (I'd like to nominate Patient to be FHIR's ADT^A01) and the first thing people latch onto when they see a resource instance is the fact that gender is a repeatable element. It isn't of course, but by the time you've explained the reasons for multiple codings people have concluded that this is over complex.

Discussed in PA work group meeting. Planning on moving forward with change so that there are 4 codes:

M - Male, F - Female, U - Unknown, O - Other.

The expectation would then be for implementers to extend Other if/where needed. This change will impact:

Organization.contact.gender

RelatedPerson.gender

Patient.gender

Patient.contact.gender

Practitioner.gender

Please note that Tracker #3220 has been closed as a duplicate.

However, the current Administrative Gender codeset is marked as a v3 codeset, should this be changed to also be a fhir defined codeset now?

regarding the following representation:
    <gender value="F" />

If we're reducing options down to a fixed code, have we considered representing these codes as whole words, like "male", "female", and "other"? The single-character representations (especially "O") are not the most approachable.

+1 for this proposed wording (which, as I read it, doesn't change behavior but clarifies it by adding vocabulary to describe it). I would note that AND and OR paramers can be combined to create an "AND of ORs" but not an "OR of ANDs." 

 

(Side node: I wouldn't use the word "composite search params" to describe the AND/OR behavior, since that term has a different meaning in FHIR. The AND/OR behavior is currently only described in the spec as a way of saying "AND/OR aren't always good enough, so that's why we have composit params.")

Sorry, that was worded badly.. I mean specifically a search for DiagnosticReports by subject patient mrn *AND* name (aka report type), which is a combination I have dealt with before. Another common combination would be subject patient mrn *AND* date range. 

With the current Profile definition, I can specify that subject patient MRN, name, and date are all valid parameters but I can't specify that they need to be used in combination. My view here is that most servers will be optimized for a set of parameter combinations, as opposed to supporting any possible combination as the reference servers do.

Ps why does this bug now show Alexander Henket as the submitter?

Thinking about this some more, another possible (maybe-less-breaking) solution would be for Conformance.Rest.Query to make the name optional (i.e. make Query.name be 0..1 instead of the current 1..1) and to add a new optional element in Query that indicates the type of resource that the query returns (I think this would be a good addition anyhow).

Ultimately the problem I'm trying to solve here is allowing servers to explicitly state that they support searching using a non-named query by "Resource.paramA *and* Resource.paramB" but not neccesarily searching by "Resource.paramA *or* Resource.paramB". This could be accomplished by putting a query in the profile that has no name or definition but has two searchParam entries.

With this allowed, a server like the Graheme's reference server could expose all of its paraemeters via Conformance.Rest.Resource.SearchParam. On the other hand, a less flexible server could specify no Conformance.Rest.Resource.SearchParam entries, but could expose it's searfch param combinations as Conformance.Rest.Query instances.

svn revsion 3090

Discussion with Grahame was that the use-case for missing system was when the expansion includes "Categories" or abstract concepts that label/group other concepts and are intended to be represented in the display or navigation of the expansion.

However - there's no clear rules for how these would actually calculated/determined when going through the automated expansion process and manual expansions that add extra "stuff" are rather problematic.  We need documentation of exactly how Grahame's use-case is supposed to work with real systems, or we need to make this 1..1.  As well, the absense of the code system as the "cue" that a given code shouldn't be selected is sort of clunky.  Sometimes the abstract categories will actually *be* codes, so suggesting they don't have a code system is inaccurate.

I would like to see more consistent use of <abstract> to handle the case that Graham mentioned as needing a cue. There's no reason why an expansion couldn't indicate codes that are present only for guidance/navigation by using <abstract> as is done in an inline coding system (<define>).
Marked as rejected because this is handled as part of task 3138

The proposed disposition is a problem because it excludes an expected behaviour that is not that unusual when dealing with expansions: the expansion includes arbitrary grouping structures that do not correspond to formal concepts (even abstract ones) defined in the underlying code system (which is why system and code are optional). Neither the define nor compose structures provide formal support for defining these arbitrary groups because there seems to be no consistency in how they are defined, and often they are not defined in the valueset. So they've been left to extensions. But making the system required prohibits this

Instead of the proposed disposition, I have done the following:
* left system as 0..1
* added a rule that if a code is present, a system must be present
* added "abstract : boolean" as decided above
* added a rule that if there is no code, abstract must be true
* added documentation of the case where there is no code/system on the contains entry
* added a note to the expand operation about why server expansions may differ from each other

Test added was changed a little in response to another task () that brought back the use of ETag:

Clients may use the If-Modified-Since, or If-None-Match HTTP header on a GET request. 
If so, they MUST accept either a 304 Not Modified as a valid status code on the response (which means that the content is unchanged since that date) or full content (either the content has not changed, 
or the server does not support conditional request).  

Servers can return 304 Not Modified where content is unchanged since the 
If-Modified-Since date-time or the If-None-Match ETag specified or they can 
return the full content as normal. This optimisation is relevant in 
reducing bandwidth for caching purposes and servers are encouraged but 
not required to support this.

it can't be talken for granted that the date is generated by tooling - for some value sets, of course, it will be. Note that the date indicates when was the status changed.  It doesn't indicate any other sort of change.  All of the HL7-defined value sets capture only a date.  If you care about the date the last version was created, that's resource metadata (sent outside the resource) and is a full timestamp.

@Lloyd: that is exactly out point: a template version is identified by id and (we call it effectiveDate) date, regardless of status, from the time it came into being until it is retired. Why is the term date "underloaded" with "date of change of status"?

I am looking for the same concept in profiles. Or we have to disaggree on how versions of profiles vs templates are identified.

Dates are not used as identifiers in FHIR.  Profile business versions are identified by Profile.version.  Profile technical versions are identified by the resource version id.  The date a technical version came into being is handled with the lastUpdateTimestamp.  The date the status of a business version last changed is handled using Profile.date.

This is a request for guidance on how to encode into SecurityEvent the details of a security-relevant event that includes security-tags. The point is to what extent are the security-tags important to record in the security event (audit log entry)? And if they are important to log, where in the SecurityEvent should be be recorded. My initial reaction is that these security-tags are unnecessary to record in the audit log. The security system was the one that creatted the security-tags, thus they could be re-identified at anytime by the security system.

The securityEvent model is based on a chain of standards (ASTM, ISO, IHE) that have as a fundimental principle that the security log should not contain unnecessary detail. This is why we only record the unique identifier of the patient, as we know we can 'look-up; the detail in the patient directory. Same goes for User (e.g. Provider), Report, Order, Result, Document, and FHIR resource instance. Thus my recommendation would be to explain this fact, which results in clear instruction that recording the security-tag is unnecessary and potentially problematic.

 

Thus the discussion recorded at the July 8th meeting does not seem to be on target.

Does updating tags create a new version of the resource now?  If not, there's still an issue because Provenance normally points to the data associated with a change by linking to a specific version.  However, if there isn't a new version created when tags change, then there's no version to point to that would convey what the tag values are.

The reason this was not added to core is because it's extremely opaque what it means. 
- this is the encounter at which the observation was requested?
- this is the encounter at which the sampling was performed? 
- this is the encounter during which it was reported? 
- this is the encounter during which it was discussed with the patient? 

For some observations, these are all the same things. For others, these are very different. I have seen this be a patient safety issue - observations filed under one encounter when people thought policy said it should be filed under another. If we add this, we need to be extremely clear about what the encounter reference means .
Reopen to discuss further what encounter means and if this belong in the core.

I don't know that I agree with this one.

While "not implemented" does sound like the right error in this case, there is a general principle that 4xx errors indicate that the client made a bad request, where 5xx errors indicate that the client made a good request but the server failed to serve it. I think I'd argue that if a server's metadata indicates history isn't supported, then this situation is a client/request screwup.

405 refers to HTTP methods (as does 501), so neither would be the right response. Given the way you make the request as described in 2.1.15 (e.g., GET [base]/[type]/[id]/_history) - the requestor is addressing a resource URL and the response should be 404 (not found). The OperationOutcome included in the body should provide an explanation that history is not supported for the underlying resource type.
18-Sept 2014: change to return a 404 in this case, with an operation outcome explaining that history is not supported. Grahame/Steve 6-0-0

I think there's a problem with this.  When you query, you don't specify a profile id.  So there's no way for the server to know what profile you're using.  And you don't want different servers returning different things in summary (though not all servers will necessarily support all elements).  Finally, servers may want to optimize to be able to return summary information more quickly (e.g. by caching it).  Varying this (and in particular, expanding it) by profile creates a problem.

It's fine to expose this - because it should appear in the resource-definition profiles.  However, it should always be the same in profiles based on a given resource.  We should explain this rule as part of the element.

practiceSetting Proposal

Add practiceSetting as a new property: DocumentReference/context/practiceSetting
    of type DocumentPracticeSetting (Example)

This property may convey specifics about the practice setting where the content was created, often reflecting the clinical specialty. This is an important piece of metadata that providers often rely upon to quickly sort and/or filter out to find specific content.

The value set for this content is bound by Example because it is a value set decided by community policy. Several examples exist for consideration:

    a value set based upon SNOMED-CT

The HumanName data type already supports multiple components (prefix, suffix and multiple given and family name parts).  What are you missing that you need that you think should be handled as part of core rather than with an extension?

Making Practitioner.name.text repeat would be inappropriate as each HumanName instance represents a single name.  However, Practitioner.name could itself be made repeating.  The question is whether most systems support multiple names for a practitioner.  If they do, we should make the element repeat in the resource.  If not, we should use an extension to capture additional names.

Further, since LDAP names are 0..* generally, it's not clear to me that we need to make Practitioner name 0..*. What's the use case in health? How many practitioners get >1 name, and what kind of circumstances is it used?

The current data model is rather anglo-centric.  It would be better if the human name data model adhered more closely to some of the recommendations outlined here: 

  http://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-personal-names

I would intepretting the 80-20 rule in this case as "there is a canonical bijective map between the FHIR data model for a human name and 80% of the types of names use world-wide."

As to the question about use case:  I am currently assisting in setting up an SMS-based health worker communication system as part of the emergency Ebola reposnse.  Here we are synchronizing between a healthcare provider directory and an SMS communicaiton bus (in this case the directory is based on CSD, but this would apply to HPD and other ).   The SMS communication bus has a JSON RESTful API, and FHIR seemed to be a natual choice to synchronzie between the directory and the communications system.  For more details, see: http://bit.ly/1qQUaPm

Another use case:  a client is executing a searching for a practitioner by, for example location, the result set for a practitioner should return all of the available names for that practitioner.  That way the user can determine that they found the correct practitioner after they have changed their name.

Also note that the current human name model has 0...* for givenName, prefix, family and suffix.  Honestly I am a bit confused by how the multiples are supposed to be used.

I read the W3 page you refer to carefully a number of times (and again, now.). I don't see the issue...? perhaps there's a subtle one around Chinese generational names. That's culture specific, just like the Dutch voorvoegsel. Other than that, it seemed ok to me

"Also note that the current human name model has 0...* for givenName, prefix, family and suffix.  Honestly I am a bit confused by how the multiples are supposed to be used.  " - a typical anglo name - John Peter Smith - 2 givens, and a family. Fromt the W3C page - María-Jose Carreño Quiñones - one given, and 2 family names. Mr Sir John Smith - 2 prefixes. (have you looked at the examples?) - in fact, give me names you think don't work, and I'll add them to the examples. 

Past names: I believe that PA determined that only a minority of systems support these. Further discussion to PA on this. (I assume that the particular use case above the HPD maintains multiple names for provider for if their name changes?)

Reading the existing documentation, it was not clear to me how I would map from IHE's CSD and HPD profiles, nor from ISO 21091:2013.     My initial intpretation on the described data model was obviously not how you were intending it to be used.  
 

It would be quite helpful, for those of use coming in from outside the FHIR community, to have more precise documentaiton on who we are supposed to interpret/map things like patronymics into the mult-value fields like givenName.   It would nice to see  a bit more precision than "see the examples."

 

Perhaps we can change the title of this bug of "Provide better documentation on the use of the humanName data model."    Not-with-standing the two items below, I don't really care which data model that you use to represent the data, I just would like to know better how to interpret it.  The two items which I would still suggest changing are:

1)Assuming that name.text is similar to "cn" or common name in LDAP data models, then make the name.text element a 0..n.   Without this, it will be difficult to represent fully the data in many existing health care provider directories as FHIR practitioner resources. 

2)Allow multiple names for a practitioner so that one can capture the distinct names that a practitioner can be referred to.  It is not uncommon for a pracitioner to change their name, to have multiple names, or mutliple representations of their names in different scripts (e.g via RFC 4646 which you mentioned on Skype).  

Then again, all of this may be out of scope for FHIR (I didn't see a clear statement about what is in considered in scope).  Having a multitude of names is certainly used in a number of common use case in the public health/health systems side of things.  Perhaps this is not needed in support of the clinical workflows that seem to be the focus of FHIR (as seems to be indicated as the pracitioner resource is being managed by Patient Administration subgroup)? 

 

Sorry for all the annoying questions.  Just trying to understand things better :-)

 

Finally, as an aside, it is noted here:

   http://gforge.hl7.org/gf/project/fhir/tracker/?action=TrackerItemEdit&tracker_item_id=3501&start=0

that "though you can't infer any particular meaning from the position in the order" for the addres data model.  This is perhaps a bit inconistent with the humanName in which it seem that one should be infering something from the position in the givenName, etc. fields.

I don't agree with making name.text 0..*. cn is just a plain string, so we should be making name 0..*, which is your second point. 

So that means that this tracker item proposes 2 changes:

* add further documentation. Maybe if we add a table showing where commonly asked things go in the name, and note that additional illustration is available in the examples (note: the examples used to be in line in the definition, but it made the page extremely long)

* Change practitioner so it has multiple names. (I agree it's not needed for a narrow interpretation of "clinical workflow", which is why it wasn't added, but the nature of FHIR is such that it will integrate directories more natively into the clinical flow, so it's not wrong to add additional names to the resource, even though it creates difficulty for many systems that only allow one name. We should provide advice about which name to take as a preference)

The purpose of the address data type (and all data types) is to capture only those elements that are supported by a significant majority of systems.  Any requirements that are limited to a few countries (or a few healthcare disciplines or organizations or projects or whatever) are handled using extensions.  Use of extensions is expected to be typical for FHIR implementations.  We've already defined one extension on address (for the US concept of "county") and will be defining many more to cover all of the nuances supported by the ISO 21090 data types.  Additional country-specific extensions are welcome and we'd be happy to publish them alongside the specification to make them easy to find.  If you think we've missed any core concepts (address parts that would be supported by the majority of software systems), please indicate.  If extensions are causing you particular grief, please explain.

Agree that clarifying that the type can be used for both postal and physical addresses would be appropriate.  We'd want to retain the term "postal address" but would want to add "physical address" as well, while also noting that it's limited to "postal style" of address - i.e. not GPS coordinates or other means of defining physical location.

Perhaps you could provide some examples. "having a 'plot'" doesn't really clarify what the requirement is here. 

As for postal vs physical - the reason we don't have this is because address is expected to be for delivery of content. If you want to describe a location, we have a location resource, and that should be used instead

Here is the UPU list of address formats for member coutries.

   http://www.upu.int/en/activities/addressing/postal-addressing-systems-in-member-countries.html

which should provide plenty of examples.

Under the assumption that FHIR aims to achieve interoperability across international borders, if I were to interpret the 80-20 rule in terms of the address data model, then it would be something like "there should be a canonical bijective map between the FHIR representation of an address and 80% of the addresses structures used in the world."  

Taking a quick glance at some of the example countries in the above link, I don't think that this is currently the case.  

I think that some small structural changes can be made to the data model which would could cover most if not all of these addresses without needing to resort to "let a country define an extension."  This could provide greater consistency across countries.

I am making the assumption here that "line" is an unordered array.  Perhaps if the order of the "line" elements had meaning, then it could work.  But then it should be clarified that order is important. 

I am not sure that simply enforcing an ordering on line elements would be enough (e.g. if you need to extract the county component of the address in the US context).  What would be more robust is to allow for and address to include key-value pairs where the keys are a code in a code system.   The code systems would be defined for each country.

I looked at several countires, including the ones you nominated and nothing leaped out at me, except for "sub-locality", which maybe is a candidate for core. It's the only extension I've seen used in practice so far. 

The lines are a list, which means that they are ordered, though you can't infer any particular meaning from the position in the order. I agree that it wouldn't hurt to make that explicit (for name parts as well). 

It sounds easy to say "key value pairs" - it sure makes life easy for the writing system that has a fully structured address (17 components for Australia, at least in the Post Office's wishful thinking version of the world), but it leaves the typical systems that don't capture these structured components out in the cold, and it makes life tough for anyone trying to read the address - how do they read it? 

Unless you want to nominate particular countries where you think there's gap, I think the only issue where is whether county / sub-locality is core or an extension

That's not a correct interpretation of the 80% rule.  The rule is "FHIR only include those address parts that 80% of systems in the world use".  So 80% of systems in the world have the concept of "country" and "address line" and "city", so those make it into the core.  On the other hand, 80% of systems through-out the world don't support the concept of "county" or "rural route number", so that doesn't make it into core.

All things that don't make it into core are handled using extensions.  You haven't indicated why using extensions is inappropriate.  

Address has two pieces.  "text" is a complete representation of the entire address (all lines, city, state, country, postal code, etc.) as it should be displayed on an envelope or equivalent.  The remaining elements are for extraction of particular information for display in individual fields in user interfaces, to aid in searching, etc.  If you need an element that isn't in the core list, you create an appropriate extension for it and use that.  So there's no need to "extract" county from the text.  You send the county as part of the text and you also send an extension that explicitly contains the county.  Any system that wants to search or filter by county uses the extension.

The key-value pair system you describe is more or less what extensions do.  They only difference is that there are certain "common" keys that we convey elsewhere for convenience and also to help encourage consistency around support of a minimum common subset.
one of the children elements used to be 1..1. The cardinality of the parent was missed when the child was changed. Now the current arrangement doesn't make sense

The reference implementations accept a number of deviations from the spec - their job is not to validate. The schematrons and the validation operation should say that this is illegal. So are we wanting to allow explicit defaults for resource element and extension definitions?  (Certainly we'd never want to allow defaults to be asserted by profiles.)
I think we should allow deafult values or default meaning, and explicitly document what they are

To be on the safe side (especially for the implementers), I think "false" in the only possible default, since many (sloppy) developers will not initialize variables to the default, so they remain "false" unless another value is explicitly stated in the instance.

The same problem lingers for fixed valueset (which we've turned into enumerations), where it's probably that the default is the first value in the enumeration.

Agree with Ewout that we could never say that the default was other than 0 / false / nil. But we clearly have situations where missing means unknown. So what I think we should do is introduce an explicit "Default Meaning" column, and document explicitly where we think that a missing value means something other than unknown. We have done this in the narrative in some cases, but we haven't done it consistently. We should say that the default, if we haven't specified otherwise, is that missing means unknown

I don't think we can say that missing means unknown.  Sometimes data will be withheld.  Sometimes it'll even be withheld at the request of the querier (e.g. Summary or a query).  No data just means "no data" - nothing can be inferred about why the data was not transmitted.

I don't think we can allow default meanings if there's any reasonable circumstance where an existing system might not know the difference.  For example, Patient.animal is not something that all systems are currently going to distinguish.  The system may well capture that it's a human or a patient in text/narrative and not have any technical mechanism of determining whether to send the Patient.animal element or not.  (Added 3655 for this specific issue)

well, I meant, unknown as in, the recipient doesn't know anything about the data. And I agree that there may be problems with assuming default meanings, which is why we should explicitly document everyone of them. We should say (a) any use of the default meaning column should be reviewed by MnM, and (b) any existing defaults (see list above) that people have an issue with, they should create a task, as Lloyd has

Further analysis with an implementer - because these elements have implicit meaning associated with null values, fixing them to null has the impact of excluding instances from the use case, not just ruling out an element as being irrelevant. This is why these elements should be tracked explicitly - helps search on them.
So are we back to "no defaults"?  Instances must contain the value?

no. I don't think we can get people to accept a practice based on "no implicit meaning for null" - not as a blanket rule. We should document it explicitly when it exists, and that will give the grounds for navel gazing about each case.

I wasn't suggesting allowing things to be null, I was suggesting adding constraints so they couldn't be, and possibly having explicit codes to convey "unknown" - but guaranteeing the instance would never have the 'defaulted' element missing.
I don't think that flys. see my previous comment  ;-)

<RelatedPerson xmlns="http://hl7.org/fhir">
 <!-- from Resource: extension, modifierExtension, language, text, and contained -->
 <identifier><!-- 0..* [Identifier] A Human identifier for this person --></identifier>
 <patientRelationship><!-- 1..* relationship of this person to a patient-->
    <patient><!-- 1..1 Resource(Patient) The patient this person is related to --></patient>
    <relationship><!-- 0..1 [CodeableConcept] The nature of the relationship --></relationship>
 </patientRelationship>
 <name><!-- 1..* [HumanName] A name associated with the person --></name>
 <telecom><!-- 0..* [Contact] A contact detail for the person --></telecom>
 <gender><!-- 0..1 [CodeableConcept] Gender for administrative purposes --></gender>
 <address><!-- 0..* [Address] Address where the related person can be contacted or visited --></address>
 <photo><!-- 0..* [Attachment] Image of the person --></photo>
</RelatedPerson>

I'm not really convinced on this one.  First, there's a question of the 80% - what do most systems do now?  I think it'd be hard to argue that most existing systems support capturing multiple relations as a single record (other than FamilyHistory - which is completely separate from this resource).  Second, combining multiple things into a single resource isn't (in and of itself) a good thing in FHIR.  The boundaries of the resource are established based on what has a natural identity and tends to be modified as a single unit of work.  In this case, that would be the relation.  Third, any record that spans multiple patients creates privacy/access control complexities.  Fourth, there are already alternate (more commonly used) solutions to managing linking of diverse patient records.

All that said, it's up to PA to decide, not me :>

Thanks for the feedback, Lloyd. With a Patient resource, associations to other Patient resources across organizational boundaries can be managed in the Links collection of the Patient resource. I'm not sure that's the common solution you had in mind, but you could certainly build a graph of patient relationships that way. But in a data sharing scenario, this isn't efficient. It would essentially require that every node in a network of Patient resources be aware of every other node. My proposal would allow implementers to create a star network of related Patient resources, where the only relationship that the Patient resource needs to know about is the RelatedPerson. As for privacy and access controls, I'm not sure how this would be a problem as a related Patient must be dereferenced from the RelatedPerson collection of patientRelationship and access controls must be in place whether that Patient reference is one Patient or many; that said, an implementer could constrain the number of patientRelationship entries to 1 only. And I don't see this as comibining things, but rather providing the necessary data structure for relating them to solve a common interoperability problem.

Well, typical behavior is a partially connected network.  Each node is aware of some of the linkages, but few know about all of them.  Where there's any capacity for a "star"-like behavior, this tends to be managed as a "Master Patient Index", where one system maintains a Patient record with knowledge of the identifiers on all subscribing systems.  The authority of this is based on the system, not the nature of the record though.  I.e. You'd still use a Patient record with a bunch of links, it's just that one system would support the coordination of the links.

Exactly right. This change is about making that use case possible - where a FHIR-based system needs to coordinate linkages between other systems. It could be an MPI, but doesn't have to be; it could also support a cross-reference of patient identities (like an IHE PIX manager). The RelatedPerson would be the FHIR resource managed by a coordinating system to relate Patient resources ingested from various patient identity domains.

It would be cleaner to do this via a distinct resource than abusing RelatedPerson (which is intended for use in capturing "next of kin" and similar relationships, not for linking diverse patient records.  For now, I'd recommend experimenting with Other and presenting your findings to the Patient Administration work group once you think it's ready to introduce as part of the core spec.  That said, it's up to PA to formally rule on this request - they may disagree with me.

PA Call 9 Oct 2014:

Discussed when to use RelatedPerson and when to use Patient.Contact. It seems that there is no guidance as to which to use.
The belief is that the RelatedPerson record should be used where it needs to be linked to other resource (such as care plan) and Patient. Contact when you have mimimal information, and don't need to re-use it (a bit arbitrary).

The suggestion to put the patient and relationship into a child component of related person seems to make sense, and would remove the denormalized data.

Further discussion is needed, and will be picked up again once some wider feedback is gathered.

Having RelatedPerson and Patient.contact seems redundant and confusing. What if we refractor RelatedPerson to only contain data concerning that person and Patient.contact linking to the resouce?

<Patient xmlns="http://hl7.org/fhir">
    <contact>  <!-- 0..* A contact party (e.g. guardian, partner, friend) for the patient -->
         <relationship><!-- 0..* CodeableConcept The kind of relationship --></relationship>
         <person><!-- 1..1  Reference(Patient | RelatedPerson) The contact resource --></person>
    </contact>
</Patient>

<RelatedPerson xmlns="http://hl7.org/fhir">
    <identifier><!-- 0..* Identifier A Human identifier for this person § --></identifier>
    <name><!-- 0..* HumanName A name associated with the person § --></name>
    <telecom><!-- 0..* ContactPoint A contact detail for the person § --></telecom>
    <gender value="[code]"/><!-- 0..1 male | female | other | unknown § -->
    <address><!-- 0..* Address Address where the related person can be contacted or visited § --></address>
    <photo><!-- 0..* Attachment Image of the person --></photo>
</RelatedPerson>

This way, we can use the same RelatedPerson with muliple Patients and Patients can have Patients as their contact person. There will be less duplication of data.

RelatedPerson is to be used when you need to record an actor in some event - who performed something, authored something, consented to something, witnessed something, etc. who wasn't either the patient or a practitioner.  Patient.contact is to capture various roles associated with the patient - who their next of kin are, who their lawyer is, who the owner of an animal is, etc.  The same people won't necessarily be in both places, though they could.

As well, RelatedPerson is patient-specific.  It's not to capture a generic "person".  We have the notion of a Person resource that we may eventually bring back to allow linking various Patient, RelatedPerson and Practitioner records to a single human being for those systems that do that sort of thing, but I think it would be wrong to attempt to make RelatedPerson into that structure.

Keep in mind that there can be privacy issues with sharing "relatives" across patient boundaries.  If one person goes to a "sensitive" clinic (abortion, std, etc.) and they find that some of their "next of kin"/other relatives are already in the system, that can provide significant insight into who else likely has been there.  As well, resource designs should align with common business practices.

Another note: The information captured for a RelatedPerson isn't necessarily sufficient to identify them as an individual.  You typically won't have date of birth, identifiers or other identity-validation mechanisms.  You'll just have "Jerry Smith", father of patient "John Smith".  The rigorous identity of the patient allows for robust identification of the related person.  If you strip the patient reference off RelatedPerson, you lose that rigor and start to force systems to have to apply the same sort of identity processes to relatives, care-givers, etc. that they apply to patients.  Forcing that sort of workflow change is inappropriate.

I would advise to keep Patient, Practioner and RelatedPerson as they are and (when ready), introduce Person as the mechanism to maintain a centralized set of demographics for those systems that support the notion and have the privacy protection mechanism in place to allow it to be used safely.
So given that Person has now been brought back, presume the proposed changes to RelatedPerson to allow it to be used in linking Patients won't be occurring?

We have a name collision resolution mechanism for search parameters.  All search parameters have a globally unique URI that defines them.  The Conformance resource indicates what parameters will be supported and the "parameter" name that will be used in URL for a given search criteria.  This might be different than the "preferred" name included in the search criteria definition.

From Lloyd: 

1. All search parameters are associated with a resource - the resource they are allowed to be used to filter.  There is no use-case for search parameters to ever be associated with a structure other than a resource.

 

2. Search criteria can be associated with:

- extensions

- core elements that don't have search criteria

- core elements that do have search criteria, but with differing behavior (e.g. sounds like, "near", within 5% of, patient age, etc.)

- combinations of core elements and/or extensions

 

Only for the first of these does tying the search parameter definition to another structure make any sense

 

3. In Conformance, each search parameter needs to be associated with a definition.  If the search criteria live on both ExtensionDefinition and on Profile/Structure, that means there's two different records that can come back.  Furthermore, there would presumably be a 0..* relationship, so they'd have to wade through multiple parameters to find the one that's relevant

 

4. We have equivalent behavior in how Conformance works with OperationDefinition - Conformance lists the name and points to the OperationDefinition that defines the operation for that name.  It will be weird not not behave the same way for Search parameters where Conformance also lists the name and points to the definition

 

5. With your proposal, the same sort of information and documentation lives in two different places.  In mine, it lives in one.

 

6. Search parameter definitions are independently identifiable (they have to be for Conformance to point to them) and are at least as independently maintainable as multiple extensions that are defined in the same context.

 

7. You haven't provided one reason why search parameters should be tied to any structure other than a resource

 

8. It's not clear  how having SearchParameterDefinition as a distinct resource creates any significant increased burden on implementers.

This doesn't sound like something that passes the 80% rule to me... Why not just define an extension?

Animal itself isn't in the 80%.  However, we made a conscious decision to include it anyhow - to make explicit that FHIR supports veterinary medicine.  If the notion of animal is in, then the notion of "is this an animal or human" has to be in, including dealing with the fact that some systems might not know.

I'd have thought that in these cases where it is an animal but don't know the type, then would want to use an "unkown" value or similar from the value set that would be included (even though the example set doesn't have one). Another alternative would be to not force the specifies value to be mandatory.

Well, the issue is that humans know it's an animal (because they can read the text comment) but the computer not only doesn't know what kind of animal it is but also doesn't know whether it's an animal at all.  The computer can't differentiate whether it's an animal or a human.  Most of the time it deals with humans, but the odd animal gets thrown in and there's no discrete element that tells the computer that.

So the problem is that we're using the presence or absence of the "animal" element to indicate whether the Patient is human.  If I don't send "animal" then that means "this instance is definitely human".  If I send "animal" (regardless of what I put inside it), then that means "this instance is definitely not a human".  But there's no way for a computer to say "I deal with both humans and non-humans and I can't say definitively which this particular patient happens to be".

What I think we need is to stop using the presence or absense of "animal" to determine whether someone is a human or not.  If we had a boolean or a code, then it'd be possible to convey "unknown".  We could make the presence of "animal" conditional on the value of the boolean/code.
not knowing it's human is the wierd case. that should be an extension, and the current design should be left the same

It would have to be a modifierExtension.  And I think it's dangerous to declare a default in the instance and expect systems where the default doesn't apply to discover and then use a modifierExtension.  I don't think failing to have a discrete value that flags an instance as being human vs. animal will be that uncommon.  As Grahame pointed out, support for distinguishing that in v2 didn't show up until 2.3.1 or later.  Systems designed primarily for humans could easily handle distinguishing using text in most cases, which doesn't help in determining whether to include Patient.animal.

This was done because of how implementers feel about context and containment. It's possible to explain that you can't have context between modular resources because of the independent access problem. But explaining why not to allow it inside a resource - when there's no access problem - is quite hard. And implementers will do this anyway, really, So it makes sense to allow it, even though it is still potentially dangerous. We could make the language stronger, I guess (though I thought that pointing out that their meaning might not be consistent might be enough)

How about this: "FHIR provides no mechanism for defining or constraining any conduction of "equivalent" properties from a containing resource into any contained resource - not even by declaring the use of a particular profile.

Best practice is to explicitly include all known properties on contained resources, even if redundant with properties on the containing resource.  E.g. If the containing resource and contained resource both have a "subject" element, both elements should be present, even if they reference the same resouce.  Servers that choose to omit redundant elements on contained resources should not expect clients to infer (or correctly infer) conducted semantics.  Clients cannot safely presume that omitted elements in contained resources can safely be inferred to be the same as the containing resource.  Any attempt to optimize resource content by 'conducting' meaning from containing to contained resources must be managed through out-of-band agreement and must be done with the recognition that any receiver not party to that agreement may not make correct (or any) inferences."

This doesn't precisely say that you can't do this, but does make clear what the ramifications are.

Having a Person resource decouples a Patient's demographics from an individual care setting and also supports a better concept of patient record linking.

If Person gets introduced, it should be optional.  Many systems would still support only Patient and Practitioner.  And Patient and Practitioner would still have their own demographics.  Systems that supported Person could choose to auto-update the linked Patient, Practitioner and/or RelatedPerson records when the Person was updated.  (Or in some cases, to update Person when an update was submitted to Patient, Practitioner or RelatedPerson.)  I.e. FHIR shouldn't force the notion of a Person registry, it should merely support the existence of one for those that need one.

We are also a software vendor in the post acute care space and support the proposal to reinstate the Person resource as defined by Peter Bernhardt above.

Gary Bartlett

Lloyd - yes, agree on all counts. FHIR should support Person registry, optionality and that Person should imply no constraints on custodianship of Person data. If used, an implementation could synchronize data between related Person-Patient, or Person-Practitioner, etc. resources. That's one use case. Person, as distinct from Patient, does support a system that allows an actor (the individual, as one example) to manage an individual's demographic data as seperate from what might be stored in a particular patient registration system.

I also work for a software vendor and we support the proposal to reinstate the Person resource as defined by Peter Bernhardt.

--Glenn Kersting
We support the proposal to reinstate the Person resource according to the definition supplied for this item.

As interoperability expands and additional provider types access patient medical records, it is important to provide a means for the patient to be able to control that access by reinstating the person resource.  It also provides an added benefit of establishing practictioner registries across multiple organizations.

The Person resource is not necessary to control access.  Keep in mind that neither Person nor Patient (or any of the others) function as a "User" resource in terms of someone who logs on and has permissions.  That's handled separately.  Once "logged in", the user is tied to a particular Patient or Practitioner or RelatedPerson role in terms of capturing who did what (author, Provenance information, etc.)  The Person resource *would* (in theory) allow linking multiple Patient records together and thus allowing consent wishes expressed against one Patient resource to be propagated to other linked Patient records, but this would be business process-specific - it wouldn't be safe to presume this would automatically happen.

I agree we should yank Money, etc. as types and use them instead as profiles.  I think distinguishing between data type and resource is useful because it implies a significant difference in the semantics of the extension.  Resource contexts are limited to specific defined paths.  Data type contexts can appear all over the place (including in new elements not yet invented).

So, maybe we should use the power of the ValueSet, and define a single defined-types valueset, that contains a hierarchical structure that mimics the conceptual structure expressed in the RI implementations:

 

Element
|-- BackboneElement
|-- Primitive
    |-- code
    |-- (etcetera)
|-- HumanName
|-- (etcetera)

Resource
|-- Bundle
|-- Binary
|-- DomainResource
    |-- Patient
    |-- (etcetera)

Then have several valuesets that express the relevant subsets for each context that I mentioned in my original comment. So, basically adding the abstract types to the valueset.

I am still of the opinion that Money etc. are real types to the user, since they are displayed and treated as such all over the place, but that's a different discussion.

The discusssions to date in Security, CBCC, FM etc. can be boiled down to (I think) the need for 2 types of signatures:

integritySignatures: Purpose to determine if content altered in transit, should break if moved. Operation sign over all content in the resource (can also apply to bundle).

documentationSignature: Purpose to determine if content altered over time regarless of movement, should not break if moved. Operation: sign over immutable portions of current resource, and follow references in the order encountered and include either: if the referred to resource has a documentation signature include the documentational signature string if any (more efficient than harvesting the SignedHash from the string) and do not follow references for this resource; if the referred to resource does not then include the immutable elements from the referred to resource and follow the references for this resource applying this same logic as you go.

Agree that we should add a page focused on digital signature issues. Comments on specific issues:

> Advice is needed for how to create a Provenance.signature and how to validate one so that the signature survives various movements. Or do we just indicate that signatures are not intended to survive movements?

The purpose of provenance signatures should be prescribed to not protect against movements. Or better, we should say that digital signatures apply at a are point in time and space.

> * How are signatures to be handled by a receiving system that imports the resource for use? That is it encorporates the resource content, and likely fixes up the References to local copies of the resource?

updates the references as required. This means that a client cannot sign content where the server is allocating the identities. This doesn't seen especially surprising. I think we should define a system level operation for pre-allocating identities to ease this problem. 

> ** Should a counter-signature be used? That is the importing system will validate the incoming signature, and then counter sign the fixedup resource, which should be a new version with a new Provenance.

I think there's a role for a counter signature. We should mention the possibility in the signature page

> * How to handle when References are included in the resource being signed?

Provenance can sign more than one resource at a time. may wish to sign the whole group

> ** Do they get turned into relative URLs?

no. they are as they are. 

> *** If a system imports the resource and 'fixes up' the References to point at local copies of the referenced resource, then the signatures will fail to validate

yes. indeed. anything else would be wrong, surely. 

> ** Do they get turned into just the unique part, without the URL root?

that might not be unique then 

> ** How are versioned Referenced resources identified?

version specific reference, if desired

> ** Do you seralize the Referenced resource along with the resource? If so how deep?

Don't understand this question

> * How to handle metadata?

we should have a canonicalization method that allows you to sign narrative + data (default), narrative + data + meta, narrative, or data

> ** Which metadata is included in the signature? Which is not?

all or none, see previous

> * How are signatures to be handled when the resource server gets re-located, changing the URL root?

non relative signatures are broken. How else could it work?
