Are you proposing that the charset no longer needs to be explicitly set since there is an implied default? That seems like it could be problematic for client libraries.
What problems do you foresee?

I'm thinking of people who aren't using a FHIR specific client library, since an out of the box HTTP library would probably assume ISO-8859-1 if it doesn't see a charset on a textual payload.

E.g. Apache HttpClient lets you access the response body as either a Java InputStream or a Reader. If a programmer picks the former they get to pick the charset (so no problem) but if they choose the latter the HTTP library would pick for them and would probably pick wrong, absent an explicit declaration. That seems like a vector for subtle bugs. Presumably similar situations exist in other languages..
they don't support media types that fix characters sets and encoding?

I'm sure many/most do, but OTOH that's not something you usualy have to worry about when writing textual HTTP clients since people pretty much always specify a charset.

I'm not suggesting that there is something fundamentally wrong with the idea of this proposal, but I think it introduces client complexity in a way, and opens a potential for bugs.. Charsets are one of those things where bugs creep in because it works fine in your test environment until the first non-english word shows up in your production environment.

I really like to be explicit. It may give a hint to someone inspecting the raw query to find an encoding bug. It signals people that they have to be prudent with this. Being implicit with regards to character encodings has proven to be the cause of errors for decades. I am not saying this alone will fix this, but I am sure it helps.

OperationDefinition allows operations and queries to be defined as being against a single resource (or multiple resources).  Defining this in Conformance.rest.resource would mean that there'd be two different ways of declaring what resource(s) an operation can be invoked against.  This would be redundant and would also open the possibility for inconsistency.  Moving the specification of the relevant resource to Conformance from OperationDefinition would be problematic because the resource(s) supported is an intrinsic part of the definition of the operation.  (E.g. requesting an "expansion" on anything other than ValueSet would be nonsensical)

Why is it problematic to look at all of the operations in Conformance.rest and see which ones are specific to the resource of interest?

from core principles:

Coded With Extensibility (CWE) means that the set of codes resolved from the Value Set Assertion is not necessarily complete for its intended use-case. There may be some concepts that need to be communicated that cannot be represented within the Value Set Assertion enumeration. Implementers therefore have permission to send local codes or original text within the coded element if an appropriate code cannot be found within the resolved Value Set Assertion. There is, however, an expectation on implementers to feed back these "missing concepts" to the maintainers of the Value Sets or referenced Code System(s) to have the necessary concept added and to transition to the 'official' code when one is added.

Coded with No Extensibility (CNE) means that the Value Set Version is considered to be complete. Use of local codes or free text is not permitted within non-null coded elements bound to the Value Set Assertion. (Local codes and free text can still be used if the coded element has a null flavor of OTH – Other.)

FHIR to align with this.

Syntax is:

type ::= typeExpression | typeExpressionList

typeExpressionList ::= typeExpression "|" type

type = normalType | resourceType

normalType = [some valid data type - not "reference"] profileRef?

profileRef = "{" [some profile URL] "}"

resourceType = singleResourceType | multiResourceType

singleResourceType = "reference(" resourceName ")" profileRef? aggregationMode?

multiResourceType = "reference(" resourceList ")" aggregationMode?

resourceList = resourceName "|" (resourceName | resourceList)

resourceName = [some valid resource name]

aggregationMode = "<contained>" | "<bundle>" | "<contained,bundle>" | "<reference>"

 

Ignore whitespace

isn't accepted = completed? I think that this means that existing status codes are too abstract and should be more domain specific

completed = The referral has been completely actioned.

In most workflows there's a step between sent and active. The referral is generally transmitted (SENT), then acknowledged by the recipient but they can't start work on it right away so it is in a queue of things to do (ACCEPTED). When work is started on the referral, ie. in progress, the referral is ACTIVE and when the referral has been completely actioned, the work is COMPLETED.

I think the statuses are pretty universally applicable. eg. FHIR change requests --> Someone drafts them (DRAFT), then submits them (SENT). You then triage them and say yep its a valid request but can't assign someone to work on it yet so it's got the status ACCEPTED. When someone starts work on it it's ACTIVE, and when the change has been made is COMPLETED.

There was a bit of a discussion about this on the implementers channel:

[26/11/2014 10:06:16 am] Brian Postlethwaite: what about an accepted status?
[26/11/2014 10:06:56 am] Brian Postlethwaite: (which is the converse of refused)
[26/11/2014 10:07:13 am] Andrew Yap: either name works for me. accepted || acknowledged. i just thought it was missing in the workflow: draft --> sent --> accepted || acknowledged --> active --> completed
[26/11/2014 10:08:28 am] Brian Postlethwaite: acknowledged just seems more like the system has received the request, but has not been processed. (messaging paradigm)
[26/11/2014 10:09:12 am] Andrew Yap: @brian: you're right. accepted implies a person has changed the status
[26/11/2014 10:09:13 am] Brett Esler: agree - it is more like a promise of care rather than just got the message

Anyways, its just my 2c :)

2.2.0.3 Extending an Operation

Implementations are able to extend operations by defining new named parameters. Implementations can publish their own extended definitions using the Operation Definition resource, and this variant definition can use OperationDefinition.base to refer to the underlying definition.
How do we ensure that local parameters don't collide with future ones defined by HL7?
You can't. I don't think that it's worth closing that loop. But we could at least say we will never define parameters starting with 'x-' or 'x_'

I think it's a bad idea to make this statement.  Name collisions can happen whether they happen with HL7 operations or externally defined operations.  We have a mechanism to manage collisions.  Suggesting people should prefix local names with x- or X_ accomplishes nothing other than suggesting an incomplete approach to managing collisions when we have a complete one.

From the ballot:

A profile extending another profile/resource must define a parent base and a differential section that defines the extension (optionally with the snapshot element).  This makes sense.

However, the differential for core resource profiles (e.g. Immunization, Procedure, etc.) is entirely duplicating the snapshot element. This is mostly an artifact of the profile generation and publishing tools rather than the FHIR spec but the spec (e.g. profile section 6.17) should clearly differentiate between top-level profiles (those with no base) and those with a base.

NamingSystem's purpose is to tie multiple identifiers together and to capture a great deal of information about a particular identifier.  There is no "canonical" id.  If you see two namespaces with active identifiers with the same value, it's relatively safe to assume they're referring to the same thing - and it doesn't matter who created the record.

Profile, ExtensionDefinition, SearchParameter, OperationDefinition and ValueSet all need to be resolvable at runtime, so it makes sense that they're all URIs.  (making the OperationDefinition name consistent would be good).  ConceptMap and COnformance aren't referenced at runtime, so breaking the pattern is probably ok.

Unfortunately, there's much more inconsistency, as pointed out by the Gist referenced. Let me emphasize that the more you break a pattern here, the more difficult it becomes to write registries and generic tools working with conformance resource metadata.

I believe, however, that it very unlikely that a healthcare-based client application is going to design an input box labeled "address" where a user would put in whatever information they want (city, postal code, street address lines,etc.). Map/almanac applications do this but they server a specific purpose which is not directly related to healthcare.

Every client application I've ever seen has a separate field for city vs. state/region vs. street address lines vs. postal code.

We're creating more unnecessary work for a server to send over a query parameter that is simply labeled "address". The server then theorertically then has to search each separate field in its database. Also, it doesn't allow the server to define matching behavior separately for the postalCode vs the street address lines. e.g. you may want to support partial matching for street address lines but only support exact matching for postal code.

conformance          Read a conformance profile for the server
read-meta               Read the meta from current state of the resource
vread-meta             Read the meta from state of a specific version of the resource
update-meta           Update meta from an existing resource by its id (or create meta if it is new)
validate-meta          Check that the meta content would be acceptable as an update
create-meta            Add meta to existing resource
transaction-meta    Update, create or delete meta on a set of resources as a single transaction

PHI or PII can end up in the logs anyway. There's no rule that the logs can only log the URL, and not the body. And if they're logging the requests, they'll be logging the responses as well. So it's not that different. Actually, the reason for indutry practice not to put things in the URL is bceause they can show up in the browser type ahead.

Allocate to Security to get a wider opinion than just mine

I agree with Grahame. The threat of web-server logs is very minimal. The web-server is handling a large amount of PHI, not just the URL. It must be properly configured, and all data that is sensitive must be appropriately protected.

Further the communications path needs to be equally protected for POST or GET; so it must be covered by HTTPS and likely client authenticated with something like OAuth.

The browser cache is likely a bigger concern, but even here there are controls that can be used to assure that the cache is flushed at the end of a session.

Rather than forbid something, I would accept that we need to do a better job of explaining that this 'risk' exists, and guide implementers to address the risk in operational and deployment controls.

Lloyd - when actually editing this xpath for the change to list, I don't understand it at all. So let's start with a plain english statement of the xpath:

- it the composition is in a bundle with type document
- the section content references must point within in teh bundle (either #local, or by base)
- and the things the references point to must be lists with List.text.div existing

 

y?

So, there's part of the path that's bogus - it says to not check for a match if there's a full URL - which of course shouldn't occur because a full URL could be a local reference.  So that part can be dropped.

The next part checks to see if the section points to a contained resource and, if so, ensures the containe resource has a narrative.  That bit works.  (Though we might want to enforce that the status says something other than "no content").

Unfortunately the next bit doesn't work anymore because we need to take into account the "base" for both the Composition resource (which affects references) and for the referenced resoruces (which affects their ids).  And the fact that base can appear at two different levels.  The resulting number of combinations of possibilities would create an xpath from hell.  We *really* need to figure out away to allow xpath-based id matching.

The tooling just generates based on what's in the spreadsheet. if you don't want it in the differential, then take it out of the spreadsheet.

The min/max column for example are required and missing them causes an error.

Also with respect to the type column having the type appear in the spreadsheet type column is very useful for profile authors to manage the profile especially if need to verify fixed values, bindings, etc.

Not having a type could lead to errors and inconsistencies but having the types forces the publish tools to add the duplicate type def into the differential profiles.

Recommend to add support for a “!” suffix to the type value to indicate to the tooling to ignore the Type but present for the profile author to see.

At present the tooling does not know how to handle a “!” prefix on the type value as it does for bindings and packages.

now I have an opinion - using 'orders' on the ground that the HL7 work group is called 'orders and..." is a very flimsy reason. It would be better if we can find a more implementer related reason.

I tend to agree with the balloter.  The name of the group is irrelevant here.  In v2, the OBR segment wasn't generally used for proposals or plans.  In FHIR, the resource very definitely serves those purposes.  If we were dealing *only* with orders, I'd be fine with the name "order", but given that the resource will now encompass plans and proposals, a more generic name seems appropriate.
I was being glib but my point is you don't call a prescription a request and you don't call lab order a request. I assumed the resource would mirror the language used in the domain.
True, but you don't call a recommendation or a care plan step an order or prescription either.  And the resource will be serving those purposes as well.

argumnent for :

My concern is that "Orders" are things that are typically privileged operations.  Lots of healthcare professionals aren't allowed to create "Orders".  And it's also going to make people think the topic is narrower than it is.  I just want to confirm that when they're voting, the work groups understand that this resource will cover everything that falls under INT in v3 - so lab promises, decision support recommendations, care plan stuff, etc.

The language of DiagnosticRequest, NutritionRequest, etc. still does not sound quite right to me.  I think it might end up being less clear and more confusing than helpful.  On the other hand, having a more general "Request" resource (not sure if that would be the right name) that covers the scope of "everything that falls under INT in v3 - so lab promises, decision support recommendations, care plan stuff, etc.", as Lloyd said, would seem potentially reasonable.  Maybe that's where things that didn't fit into DiagnosticOrder, NutritionOrder, etc. could go?  

The V3 RQO UsageNote discussion does appear to be germane here:

The concepts of a "request" and an "order" are viewed as different, because there is an implication of a mandate associated with order. In practice, however, this distinction has no general functional value in the inter-operation of health care computing. "Orders" are commonly refused for a variety of clinical and business reasons, and the notion of a "request" obligates the recipient (the fulfiller) to respond to the sender (the author). Indeed, in many regions, including Australia and Europe, the common term used is "request."

Thus, the concept embodies both notions, as there is no useful distinction to be made. If a mandate is to be associated with a request, this will be embodied in the "local" business rules applied to the transactions. Should HL7 desire to provide a distinction between these in the future, the individual concepts could be added as specializations of this concept.

So I might be persuaded that changing to the use of "request" rather than "order" is a reasonable step to take, as long as we do it consistently.

From a purely technical perspective, it seems like a <Link> element within an ATOM feed with a rel value of "self" would do the trick (RFC 4287).

Let's assume, however, for a moment that Patient/Person is just a special use case that needs to be accounted for. I think that it is important to consider who is going to be doing the linking of disparate patient resources. I'm extremely skeptical that this would be healthcare providers. Rather, I believe that the patient or a proxy for the patient would do any and all linking. They would do so via the key identifiers that the organization provides to them e.g. log-in username/id. To meet the aggregation use case, it seems like the resource should be something more along the lines of "Account List" vs. "Person". The "Account List" resource would track the organizations (and/or FHIR Servers) where the patient has information. It would also then include key information that facilitates the linking (which wouldn't necessarily be demographics).

MnM review: We use different mechanisms based on use-case.  For "master person indexes", having a Person resource makes sense.  For terminologies, we have ConceptMap.  For some resources, there may be an explicit "replaces" relationship.  We can also define equivalences via extension, etc.  It doesn't appear that we can (or should) attempt to apply a one size fits all solution.  Balloter has asked for more discussion within PA.

From discussion in the PA WGM, The real differentiation between Patient.Link and Person.Link is that Patient.Link is usually considered internal Patient references, and managed internally.

Whereas Person.Link is to be used for external Person registries, such as membership systems. Another factor influency the design is that the "Person managing system" may not have write access into the Patient system.

We should add in a new section above Person and Linking titled "Patient vs Person" and include additional guidance (covering what is mentioned above).

There will remain some ambiguity between see also and Person Linkages.

The section also needs to cover what implications this could have on a client applications searching for patient/person.

I would like to pull 5273. My comment was found not persuasive, but I don't understand why. I did not say that Imaging "Reports" should be observations. I said "imaging data" (perhaps I should have said "imaging results" instead). My comment referenced section 4.21.7. Specifically, I looked at the XML for the DXA Bone Densitometry imaging example.
http://hl7.org/implement/standards/FHIR-Develop/diagnosticreport-example-dxa.xml.html

in which one of the measurements in the imaging report is shown as an observation (see below copied from that page)

<Observation><!-- Here is one of the measurements above encoded as an observation for example purposes. --> <id value="r1"/> <name> <coding> <system value="http://loinc.org"/> <code value="24701-5"/> <display value="Femur DXA Bone density"/> </coding> </name> <valueQuantity> <value value="0.887"/> <units value="g/cm²"/> <system value="http://unitsofmeasure.org"/> <code value="g/cm-2"/> </valueQuantity> <status value="final"/> <reliability value="ok"/> <bodySite> <coding> <system value="http://snomed.info/sct"/> <code value="71341001:272741003=7771000"/> </coding> </bodySite> </Observation>

The word "diagnostic" would, to clinicians, encompass many types of observations, and I thought that my proposed wording change included extra examples that were within the scope of observations, and would bring more clarity. "In contrast to Observation resource, the DiagnosticReport resource typically include additional clinical context and and some mix of atomic results, images, imaging reports, textual and coded interpretation, and formatted representations.  Laboratory reports, pathology reports, and imaging reports should be represented using the DiagnosticReport resource. Group is something that can be referenced in place of another entity for when actions are done to a group.  For example, observations done to a group, procedures done to a group, etc.  It is expected to be used for public health and clinical studies but may also be used in other places where patients, devices, etc. are tracked and/or manipulated as a group.  The key differentiators with list are:

Groups can be acted upon

Groups are restricted to containing "entities", not actions.

 

Need to improve the documentation in Group and List to make this clear.
Recommendation: Include above content in definition of Group to clarify relationship to List

I see in clinicalAssessment Resource you have the following - 

Careplan  - A specific careplan that prompted this assessment

Referral - A specific referral that lead to this assessment

 

I'm requesting adding one for order. So will have 

Order - A specific order that lead to this assessment

Rationale: when nurses implement an order, we do an assessment first to ensure that the indication for the order is appropriate (we don't just do the order). For example - start patient on full liquid diet post op day 2. the nurse will assess the patient for bowel sounds, free of nausea and vomiting, and assess if the patient will be able to tolerate the full liquid diet (i.e. the patient is tolerating the current diet before implementing the full liquid diet). Or, start wet-to-dry dressing - nurses will assess the wound and make sure there is a need for the order (indication is appropriate) before we implement the order. We need to be able to document the assessment and say why we did the assessment.

Referral is actually a type of order.  We could add DiagagnosticOrder though.  We might want collapse all 3 together into an element called "request" - "A specific request or order that prompted this assessment"

The signature in provenance is there to prove that the resource has not changed from the intended resource which the provenance describes. This is just one use of a digital signature.

It would be inappropriate to use a provenance resource to do a signature like a signature for the purpose of Reviewed&Approve, OverRead, Co-Sign, etc.

So the approach is to create a signature resource that can be used for any purpose. In this resource we would expose who, when, why, as more easily accessible; although the non-repudiatable versions of these are within the signature block.  This signature would be similar to Provenance but not limited to "Provenance". It is possible that Provenance is changed to point at this Signature resource (Guidance welcome).

Alternative is that we relax what we mean by Provenance, and change Provenance to something more like Evidence (likely need to cast that, as the single word evidence will be confusing in healthcare), or Lifecycle (record lifecycle events).

To do the variable dosing, you would use multiple dosage instruction elements.  The first one would have a dose of 500mg (or 2 tablets) with a timing of 1 day.  The second element would have a dose of 1 tablet with a timing of 4 days.

the Resource(Medication) would contain the details of Penicillin and Normal Saline.  The dosageInstruction.doseQuantity would have 50mL.
Attached is the file with proposed core identifiers to start with.

Before worrying about the specific ids, I'd like us to define the rules for what can go into the vocabulary.  At minimum, we should include the following:

* Any codes added need to be universal in scope - nothing limited to a single country or region

* All codes need to be orthogonal - there must be no chance that a single identifier could be interpretted as falling withing multiple codes

* Codes need to fall within the 80% of identifier types for at least one kind of resource.  I.e. 80% of systems using that resource would support using that type of identifier for that type of resource

 

All other codes would need to be handled by the "extensible" aspect of the binding.  If you want something finer grained, you would need to send the general "international" code as well as the more specific local code.

The objective of these rules is to avoid ending up with a plethora of overlapping and/or confusing codes.

Will add "code" to the Identifier type as 0..1 CodeableConcept.  Binding as "extensible" (must use one of the approved codes if one applies - for interoperability, can supplement with local translations or with additional codes if none of the HL7 codes applies).  Will add usage notes that the code is not a substitute for "system" and that codes should not be defined that are 1..1 with system.  Will add the above guidance on what codes will be accepted into the HL7-maintained value set as part of the definition.

I was looking specifically for an explanation how we formal vocabulary bindings to element defintions in a profile ( e.g. static/dynamic, intentional or extension value set) like the ones described in "Core Principles and Properties of HL7 Version 3 Models" http://www.hl7.org/v3ballotarchive_temp_93AB0631-1C23-BA17-0C7C527F6EF0F1FA/v3ballot2014sep/html/infrastructure/coreprinciples/v3modelcoreprinciples.html 5.2 Vocabulary Conformance 5.2.1 Vocabulary Declaration 5.2.2 Value Set Assertion 5.2.2.1 Value Sets Declared In Assertion 5.2.2.2 Coding Strength 5.2.2.3 Stability Level 5.2.2.4 Expression of Value Set Assertions 5.2.3 Conformance with Value Set Assertions 5.3 Vocabulary Binding 5.3.1 Model Binding 5.3.2 Context Binding 5.3.3 Choosing a Binding Type 5.3.4 Binding Syntax By the way, there some broken links to potentially useuful examples: http://www.hl7.org/implement/standards/FHIR-Develop/diagnosticreport-profile-lipids.html referenced in: http://www.hl7.org/implement/standards/FHIR-Develop/profiling-examples.html

Well, we don't use terms like intensional/extensional or static/dynamic.  The specification doesn't presume or depend on any knowledge of Core Principles or terminology expertise in general.  The explanation of how to do binding is in ElementDefinition (search for binding and look at the structure).  You'll also want to look at the ValueSet resource.  And read http://hl7-fhir.github.io/terminologies.html too.

Please raise the broken links as a separate tracker item.  (Ensure they're still present in the continuous integration site first.)

There's also this page:

http://hl7-fhir.github.io/terminologies.html

FHIR Terminology add "incomplete" and "example" bindings without defining them or relating them to "dynamic" or "reference" value sets. My suggestion was that if the FHIR terminology specification is relating new concepts ("incomplete" and "example") to existing and painstakingly defined vocab concepts it would be easier for implementers to adopt. I believe the Core Principles is referenced in the FHIR frontmatter but I could be wrong on that score. At any rate, it would be useful to reuse the definitions and concepts already defined even of we choose to use some and ignore others.
I think this was largely resolved as part of #3183 rewrite of status codes. These have explicit relationships into the core principles.

I think making FHIR's "http operations" (update, delete, read) explicit in transaction bundles would improve the understandability of the spec, and actually make it easier to implement consistently. The same logic would apply in an bundle as for a bunch of http operations. (An added bonus, which would address a use case I've heard from many corners: we could support "read" and "vread" in transaction bundles, as well, which would allow more effecient execution of multiple reads.)

I'm not sure about extending this beyond FHIR's "http operations", but I really do think it's worth considering. I don't believe this adds to the complexity: by defining a trivial mapping between fhir "http operations" (and possible FHIR Operations, too) and transaction bundle entries, server-side logic becomes directly re-usable.

Section 6.15.6

The focus has been on the exchange of content models to support business activity, in which case the only status would be 'done' as the claim when delivered is immutable. Are you suggesting that there is a need for an additional status when crafting a claim on the local system to indicate that it is in-development or complete or sent?

The StatusRequest and StatusResponse are needed when you don't have Operations. Our aim is to provide the reosurces to support the business regardless of transport chosen. A REST implementation may use an operation or query to satisfy a business function, a SOA exchange or other RPC-style exchange may not have that capability. Also, StatusRequest is not asking for the status of the resource, it is asking for the state of processing of the resource.

StatusRequest has been rolled into ProcessRequest, StatusResponse has been renamed to ProcessResponse.

This needs to be thought of as a local implementation of a global solution. The GUDID is the FDA repository, other repositories will probably be established in other jurisdictions over time.

Amended Proposed Wording:
 The most important of the identifiers is the Unique Device Identifier (UDI). The UDI has 2 components -- the device identifier (DI), which is assigned at the version/model level of the device and the production identifier(s)(PI) which provide the means to track a device through its manufacture, distribution and use. The UDI string may aslo contain additonal elements which are not formally part of the local defined UDI elements but which are non the less contained within the same string and are of value locally. The DI of the UDI may be stored in a jurisdictional respository and used as the primary key to access other device information. The UDI may identify an instance of a device uniquely (when the PI(s) include a serial number), or it may just identify the type of the device. The UDI can be broken into its constituent parts (DI, PI and other elements) by parsing rules developed by each Issuing Agency standard. Where the device has an assigned UDI, the other details carried in the resource (e.g. lot, expiry date etc) SHALL be consistent with the information encoded in the UDI string or registered in the GUDID.

In the US, a UDI will be required by the FDA for every medical device to bear on its label (unless excepted). The DI of the UDI is submitted in a device record to the Global Unique Device Identification Database (GUDID) and is used as the primary key to access other device information.
Change ~~ information encoded in the UDI string or registered in the GUDID to ~~ information encoded in the UDI string or registered in the local repository.

There are no 'executable functions' in the UDI barcode. There are in some barcodes, such as GS1, unprintable characters, ASCII Control Characters, so the Human Readable form of the content is used. The protocol, at least as far as http and https are concerned are exchangeable and not considered to define a separate object but rather are expected to refer to the same object.

The portion of the url after the protocol is particular to the object including the specication of ports: While http://machine and http://machine:80 may be equivalent, for FHIR they are not considered identical due to the prevalence of port mapping. Consequently ports should only be explicit when they have explicit meaning to the server.

For example:

http://myserver,com/patient/1 and https://myserver.com/patient/1 are the same while http://myserver.com:80/patient/1 is distinct from either of the above.

It is recognized that this means url comparison http and https are equivalent, and that the comparison to other protocols is undefined.

LLoyd, do you have a recommendation for what elements are necessary for the 80%? Otherwise your argument is rather nonpursuasive.

And how do the following meet this dogma that profiles must meet some very subjective 80% rule>

 

~~• SDC profiles - Profiles on the four FHIR resources used to support the IG requirements:
o SDC Data Element (DE) Profile - Constraints and extensions for capturing data elements
o SDC Questionnaire Profile - Constraints and extensions for capturing form designs
o SDC Questionnaire Answers Profile - Constraints and extensions for capturing form data instances
o SDC Value Set Profile - Constraints and extensions for defining lists of allowed codes
• Pre-population Operation - The definition of the custom service that allows pre-population of forms based on CDA and other data sources

Patient, type, applicable period, signed date, signer, organization, text.

And actually, the onus is on the WG to demonstrate to at least some degree of confidence that the vast majority of systems that support any type of consents are capable of capturing every single one of these data elements.  In cases of uncertainty, we err on the side of making things an extension rather than core for the DSTU period.  I've seen a couple of Canadian systems and they didn't do more than the above.  (And the type, organization and text weren't actually captured on the grounds that they were fixed based on context, though I think it's reasonable to expect these to be explicit in FHIR.)

Keep in mind that we're representing what real systems actually choose to capture in discrete data, not how information in paper forms might be modeled.

Lloyd,

Those are the things that the ConsentDirective profiles as necessary. There are some other optional elements. Are you suggesting that these other optional elements should not be included, but rather must come from extensions?

As optional, they don't need to be included. But as optional, and well defined, when they are needed they will be used in a consistant way.

Which elements cause you the most concern?

John

The SDC, DAF and other questionnaires are realm and context-specific.  They can include whatever they like.  However, the Consent profile is similar to the forthcoming Immunization profile.  It's essentially constrained to resource rules - it must be context neutral - it has to apply to every country in the world, every type of consent in the world and needs to, as much as possible, reflect what existing systems do now, not necessarily what we think they ought to do.  Also note that SDC makes *significant* use of extensions to cover a lot of its functionality.  Almost half of the data elements in the Questionnaire profile are extensions.

The 80% has nothing to do with what's optional.  If we don't think the vast majority of systems capture something, then it shouldn't be included in the profile at all.  (You can define common extensions for those elements if you wish.)  We don't use resources or resource-level profiles to define best practice or even good practice.  That's left to more refined profiles (e.g. the genomics profile on FamilyHistory).

Note: 80% isn't dogma.  It's a core principle of FHIR.  It is somewhat subjective, but not terribly.  Most WGs have found very few elements where there was dispute when they focused on the question of "how many of the wide variety of systems that currently do what this resource does support this functionality right now?". If you can point to systems in multiple jurisdictions with different cultures and multiple types of consent that all support the element and don't have a lot of counter-examples of systems that support consent but don't support the element, that's fine for 80%.  Where work groups tend to struggle is when they believe systems *should* do something but don't currently and they're reluctant to handle that as an extension.  The FHIR approach in such situations is to define it as an extension during the DSTU period (and maybe create a "good practice" profile that uses the extension) and to see what implementer uptake is during the DSTU period.

Lloyd - unfortunately, this tracker venue is not open enough to get input from others and very clumsy for trying so send the string of comments to others  - but I'll make sure ask that this be added to the CBCC agenda. 

RE Canada - is your perspective shared by Stanley Ratajczak and others in Infoway?  Did you include the Pharmanet system in your review?  How about the customers for HIPAAT, which is a Canadian Consent Directive Management Co.  In the US, ONC has multiple pages dedicated to Meaningful Consent, the Consent2Share Open Source application, and other endeavors.  But we should definitely get the members of CBCC and Security who have been working in this area for many years to give input.

As for SDC - there are only a few extensions and as far as I know US systems now do what that FHIR IG and profiles on FHIR Questionnaire/QuestionnaireAnswer Resources. I think we need to take this type of argument to TSC because we're just spinning wheels.

It's not a question of perspective.  There are lots of implementations of consent in Canada and they're all very simple structures.  And yes, that includes PharmaNet.  We're not trying to design what consent *should* be or what best practice is.  We're designing what's currently in broad use.  What *should* be (or what a particular group's opinion is of what should be.) can be handled through context-specific profiles.  The base Consent resource/profile needs to follow the 80% rule.  Derived profiles that bind themselves to specific contexts (e.g. U.S. meaningful use, best practice according to whoever, etc.) can make things as complicated as they wish.  But that complication is done using extensions.

The SDC profile for Questionnaire is here: http://hl7-fhir.github.io/questionnaire-sdc-structureddatacaptureform.html.  Over half of the elements on it are extensions.

This isn't a TSC question.  It's an FMG/FGB question.  FGB sets the guiding principles for how FHIR resources and profiles need to be structured.  FMG manages that process and ensures everyone complies.  TSC isn't going to override fundamental precepts of how FHIR works.

It's perfectly fine to have a Profile that contains the exact same structures you have in the current profile - but that needs to be a profile with a base of Consent and much of the content needs to be handled through extensions.  The base Consent structure (whether it's a profile or a resource) needs to adhere to the 80% rule.

~~Dogma is a principle or set of principles laid down by an authority as incontrovertibly true. It serves as part of the primary basis of an ideology or belief system, and it cannot be changed or discarded without affecting the very system's paradigm, or the ideology itself.

The term Dogma isn't used to assert whether something is a good or bad idea.

In that case, then yes, 80% is dogma.  It's a core principle of FHIR design.  It's not an immutable principle - deviations can and have occurred.  However, it's something we adhere to pretty strongly.

Might I suggest that the ConsentDirective project include a "Basic-ConsentDirective" that supports blanket consents without exceptions. Essentially the common HIE policies from BPPC. These would be scoped to sharing beyond the original organization and purpose for which the health information was created. This form of a Consent Directive would need only (identifier, issued, applies, subject, authority, domain, type=consent, subtype=<some vocabulary>, and possibly friendly and legal). This Basic Consent Directive would support the following HIE subtypes:

1) Opt-In -- Agree to publish "All" healthcare information. Agree to Use and Disclosure to "any" authorized individual of a "Treatment" or "Payment" organization "For the Purpose" of "Treatment" or "Payment". No Redisclosure allowed without further authorization. This agreement does not authorize other accesses.

2) Opt-Out allowing break-glass -- Agree to publish "All" healthcare information. Agree to Use and Disclosure to "any" authorized individual of a Treatment organization for specifically "Emergency Treatment" PurpoeOfUse, and Payment of those treatment. This agreement does not authorize other accesses.

3) Opt-In summary access only -- Agree to publish "All" healthcare information. Agree to Use and Disclosure to "any" authorized individual of a "Treatment" or "Payment" organization "For the Purpose" of "Treatment" or "Payment"; to only the medications and allergies summary. No Redisclosure allowed without further authorization. This agreement does not authorize other accesses.

4) Opt-In break-glass summary access only -- Agree to publish "All" healthcare information. Agree to Use and Disclosure to "any" authorized individual of a "Treatment" organization "For the Purpose" of "Emergency Treatment" and Payment of those treatment; to only the medications and allergies summary. No Redisclosure allowed without further authorization. This agreement does not authorize other accesses.

5) Opt-Out no break-glass -- Agree to publish "All" healthcare information. This agreement does not authorize any accesses.

6) Opt-Out completely -- Agree to publish "No" healthcare information beyond originating organization intended use.

From email to CBCC:

I had an action item from last call to point to the documentation that explains the difference between the different types of profiles.  Specifically, the difference between "good practice" profiles and "key" profiles.  That documentation is here:

http://wiki.hl7.org/index.php?title=FHIR_Profile_and_IG_Balloting

 

You'll note that that documentation doesn't discuss whether the 80% rules apply when dealing with "key" profiles - that wasn't one of the considerations when we wrote up the document.  However, in subsequent discussion within the FMG, there is consensus that for "key" profiles, the same rules apply as for creating resources.  So elements should reflect the 80%, vocabulary bindings and other constraints should be permissive of the full possible range of implementations through-out the world in a wide variety of contexts, no elements should be marked as "must support", etc.

 

These rules do not apply to "best practice" profiles which are assertions by a WG as to how systems *should* behave, most likely in a more narrow context.

 

I would support the proposal from John to proceed to ballot with profiles that reflect both types of behavior:

 - a "key" profile that reflects the lowest common denominator of what's done around patient consent right now and adheres to the rules for resource authorship

- a "good practice" profile which complies with the "key" profile, but asserts what the CBCC work group believes systems should be striving towards.

 

Compliance with FHIR around consent would only require adherence to the "key" profile, but implementers could choose to comply with the more stringent profile, and regulatory bodies could choose to enforce the more stringent profile if they wished.

Most implementers should be interacting with the object model.  And there's no issue with the object model having both - and the object model can enforce the invariant by changing the boolean to true if the deceased date is set and by throwing an exception if you try to make the boolean false.  If the object model isn't currently doing this, I think it should.  However, the wire format shouldn't allow transmission of data that could be inconsistent and I don't see enforcing that restriction as necessarily adding any complexity to implementers, given that most will simply interact with the object model exposed by the reference implementations.

Recommendation: Move this to a tooling issue such that the reference implementations properly handle serialization of object models where multiple properties are set (and in fact, properly set boolean properties when date is present).

Certainly there needs to be some clarity here.  If the given names listed are as you stated, the FHIR interpretation would be that her name is:

"Kathleen Kathy Kay Smith Jones" (In my case, the given name section for me would be "Lloyd", "Robert", "William", as I have two middle names.

If the intention is that Kathleen, Kathy and Kay are alternates, then that would be reflected by having separate repetitions of the entire name structure with each variant (one possibly being the "official" name and one being the "preferred" name).

In any event, you shouldn't have to worry about the name parts at all because the full name - as it's expected to be rendered based on cultural norms (which sometimes result in differing orders for family and given names) is specified in HumanName.text.  That should almost always be populated.  The name parts are intended for use in searching/filtering, not usually for rendering.  (It may be this needs to be made more clear too . . .)

A condition covers both point-in-time diagnosis as well as assertions (and management) of longer-term conditions.  The notion of a problem list is dealt with through the combination of this resource as well as the List resource.  The identifier would not change over the lifetime of the condition.  You could update severity (and even type of condition) over time.  And you could go look at the history of the resource instance to see how it has evolved over time.  You can look at the onset date and the abatement date to look when the condition was present, even if the current date is now years later.  Given this, it's not clear that another resource is needed.

Hi Lloyd.

Your suggestion sounds appealing, but unfortunately does not work.  This is because there is no way to uniquly identify history elements within a single concern, and it assumes that a single identifier is always known in advance, and it isn't always.

For example, consider the following scenario.

System A = problem repostory 

System B = client 1 - system creates notes, and sends problems to the problem repository.

System C = client 2 - edits the problem list in the problem repository.

time 1) System A has no problems

Time 2) System B creates a note and send problems - E.g. Patient has Diabetes (controlled)

Time 3) System C sees that the probelm Diabetes exists so gets a problem from A and edits/updates. E.g. Patients Diabetes is (uncontrolled).  It does not create a new problem because one exists.

Time 4) System B realizes that note was generated on wrong patient, and the observation it sent was invalid.  Sends System A - Diabetes = Error.

How should System A resolve?   Should Diabetes be marked erroneous?   Answer,  No.  In this case there is another observation that is newer, but the system B has no way of identifying that the observation to remove is the instance at timepoint 2.  

If Note that if system B had NOT sent and event, however the answer is yes. 

Acutally, you can't even use timestamps for this because its not safe - System B and C could send at exactly the send events at exactly the same time.   Also, System A can't rely on even the distinction between System B or C to keep strait since the same system may send incorrect messages and correct messages at different points in time.

BTW, this is a real example, and it created a mess  System A did have an event history but it was basically impossible to sort out. because System B had no way to see it, or clarify which events it had sent.  

There is another problem in that if System B sends an problem without checking to see if that problem exists on System A first, then to merge this problem System A needs to change the instance ids on events from System B.    So merging problems becomes a nightmare and cleaning up the problem list becomes near impossible.

Hi Larry,

There's no issue around detection of collisions.  Every version has an etag and a timestamp, so system B will be aware that the diabetes record has been updated since they last recorded it.  They would be forced to re-query and would have to then make the decision about whether their notion that the diabetes was in fact non-existent for that patient was correct - likely by picking up the phone.  Only after they had confirmed the correct course of action would they update the system B record.  The resolution of the ETag mechanism is *required* to detect collisions, no matter how close the updates are made.

Presumably where you say "System B" you mean System A - the repository.  

If I understand correctly, then in this case then basically what I've been calling the "event id" is basically the condition identifier + etag+timestamp (?) and what I've been calling the "concern id" is just the condition identifier.

OK.  Helpful, but then more questions.  I'm still struggling to see how I could make this work using your etag solution.

1) how does one represent that a condition was seen on 3 different encounters and see what dates those visits occured?  

2) how does one correctly merge conditions and do cleanup work?  E.g. system B records "Rash", and System C records "Uticaria", and "System D" records "Skin Lesion", and these all get sent under different ID's, then somebody looks at all these and decides they are all the same, so they all get merged into "Rash".  How do system C and D know that the records they sent are now related under a different id's history?  E.g. When the path result comes back and now shows that the "rash" is now a skin cancer, how does System C know that this is related to the thing it called (and still calls) Uticaria?  Can the etag indicate that a resource is now replaced by?   

3) Many systems just send information.  These systems can't be made to just 're-query' the problem list.  Eg.  A NLP parse of a document can find problems and send to a problem list, but it doesn't query the problem list.  A pick of a structured problem in the note might have the condition id to send for matching, but that can't be guaranteed.  A prior event ID can be identified, but the condition id might not even be known when it sends.  These ID's still need to be resolved on the repostitory side (e.g. add if not already there).   Theres absolutely no way a system like this can "pick up the phone" to resolve something based on an event like the fact that the entire "document was made erroneous".  It could problably identify the prior event id's but system B may not even have a condition ID yet.

Yes.

Each version of the resource has an identifier and a timestamp.  The current version has an etag that changes each time the resource is updated (it could be the version id, but need not be).

Tracking that a condition was seen (or any other record was seen) is done using SecurityEvent.  While it's possible for that information to be queried, I wasn't aware that it was common practice (except for audit, legal and other purposes) for clinicians to examine who looked at what record when.  The dates of the encounters would be captured in their specific encounter records.

Linking "replaced" records to the "replacing" record isn't part of core in FHIR, but could be done using extensions.  (Not a lot of systems have this level of sophistication/coordination.)  I'd be comfortable with a change request to define a common extension for this purpose though.

Sending new data to a problem list (e.g. from an NLP parse) would not attempt to update existing records, it would just add new records to the list.  A human would then currate the list and have to determine what of the newly added data should be combined with existing entries, what should be retained and what should be removed.  I guess in theory, an automated algorithm could attempt it, though it would have to be pretty impressive.  In any case, you could look at Provenance to see exactly what changes had been made during the reconciliation process.

Patient Care 1/29/15 -- end up with two flavors of issues.  Problem lists have a mix of conditions -- added at different points of time,or it is blank because no one is using the problem list.  An observation is always true, but the problem list is not always true.  Is a problem list curated?  The list resource is used - but the list can convey with is changing on the list.  A condition can be asserted and then removed as well as a status.  1. Curation available? 2. Allow any user to curate?, 3. does FHIR support this curation of the condition?  There will be a list for the PCP, the cardiologist....   Need a history of a particular item on the list based on the source.  Need to link various lists to ensure reconciliation (based on EHR functionality).

Condition can be used to capture point-in-time snapshots (diagnosis, symptom) as well as curated objects (problems).  FHIR has List resources.  In principle, there can be hundreds of them, maintained by anyone.  In practice, organizations will figure out what lists will exist, whether they'll be shared or practitioner-specific and what the curation mechanisms will be.  It's entirely possible for problem lists to include multiple occurrences of a problem as well as certain problems that have resolved (but are still of interest).
Both of these things need to be fixed.  Hold off on fixing the transform until bundle revisions are revisited

http://hl7.org/implement/standards/FHIR-Develop/valueset-definitions.html#ValueSet.compose.include

profile removed so no longer applicable-

Expanding a little on this part: do include/exclude also operate on the imported value set(s), or only on code system?

If include/exclude are meant to also operate on imported value sets then it is kind of impossible enforce include/exclude on the expanded version of the imported value set. The imported value set could again be an intensional value set that imports other value sets etc. So what you could do is

- recursively retrieve every import and imports in imports
- consider the result of all imports as a large set of includes and excludes and then calculate the outcome.

This approach fails if any imported value sets operate on a codesystem only known to the server that had the value set that the include came from.

If it points to a URI rather than a value set reference, you can't do an expansion.  The URI could point to a web page, an FTP site or pretty much anything.  The format of the content isn't defined.

Circular references should be handled by the expansion algorithm.  I.e. Implementing the "expand" operation purely through recursive calls is inadviseable.

Order of operations is: union all imports, add on all includes, remove all excludes.

Certainly it's possible that a reference won't be resolvable and an expansion won't be possible.

Happy for the above to be clarified in the specification.

Since import is a URI, and cannot be a reference, then expansion of any import is out of scope?

What's expected behavior when expansion fails on import while include/exclude works: fail all? return partial results with or without OperationOutcome?

I thought we'd done value set reference for pointers to real value sets, but I guess not.  So you'd have to try to resolve the URI.  If it gives you a value set, you can expand.  If it gives you HTML or something else, then you can't.  Agree this should be clarified.  And may make sense to change to a choice of URI vs. Reference(ValueSet) to avoid the need to try to resolve when determining whether you can expand.
Agreed with Lloyd up to the end. Don't understand the last idea - you have to try to resolve either way. It just introduces needless syntactical variation

The purpose of the last change is optimization.  If it's a URI, you don't need to try to resolve.  You can't generate an expansion on a URI, so wouldn't bother to try.  You'd only try to resolve if it was a Reference(ValueSet).
I don't think that introducing that optimization is a net win.

Add a new element reference:

reference         0..*  Element     Identifiers or resources related to, but not identifying, the document

+ identifier      0..1  Identifier  An identifier related to the document

+ resource        0..1  DomainResource    A resource related to the document

Details:

DocumentReference.reference

Definition: Related identifiers or resources associated with, but not identifying, the document, such as an accession number, Order, or workflow identifier.

Comments: Other references can also include Order Numbers or resources, Referral Request Identifiers, XDS Workflow Instance Identifiers.

DocumentReference.reference.identifier

Definition: An identifier related to the document.

Comment: If both identifier and resource are present, they shall refer to the same entity.

DocumentReference.reference.resource

Definition: A resource related to the document.

Comment: If both identifier and resource are present, they shall refer to the same entity.

 

Outstanding issues:

1. Does this need to be searchable? If so, how?

2. Should DocumentReference.reference.resource be limited to specific resource types?

3. Do we need to provide guidance on use of identifier or resource? Do we prefer resource if there is a FHIR equivalent? Do we want both? How do we reconcile or document that DocumentReference.reference.identifier may not match the DocumentReference.reference.resource.identifier (for example, if the DocumentReference.reference.identifier is taken from XDS metadata with a value of "134467653^^^1.2.3.4.5.42.1^urn:ihe:iti:xds:2013:order", then it is unlikely that the corresponding Order resource will use "urn:ihe:iti:xds:2013:order" as the system). How much of this belongs in the DocumentReference definition, and how much in a FHIR profile or in MHD?

4. There is currently a DocumentReference.identifier element with a nearly identical definition. Clarify that DocumentReference.identifier is an identifier for the document, but DocumentReference.reference is an identifier/resource related to the document.

There are challenges with having "title" on List.  It gets kind of wonky when Document.section has title and Document.section points to List which also has a title.  We don't want to remove Document.section.title because it's possible for the document title to be specific to where the list appears in the document and also for documents to have rules about what the title must be.  (And you don't want to have to revise the title of the List instance to comply with a document profile.)

I'm not totally opposed to having a title on List, just that we need to think through the ramifications and make clear what happens when there are titles in multiple places.

We've discussed this at length before. Firstly, there's no right answer for whether you want a shallow or a deep comparison on equals. Secondly, overriding equals can have some deeply unexpected answers in hash maps, etc. So every time, we agree not to override equals, and I think it's the right decision. but we did decidel, and I see haven't done this - to generate equivalent methods for both deep and shallow, so that they are there for if you want them

This has been an ongoing discussion on the HAPI v2 library community as well for many years (seriously, it's been 12+ years!).

I'm of the opinion that supporting equals/hashCode on the HL7 domain objects (either for v2 or for FHIR) is a bad idea, since it's ambiguous what should be compared. Do you compare just the object itself, or other nested referenced objects? How do you treat values that are logically equivalent even if they aren't identical? etc etc etc..

Having explicit deepEquals and shallowEquals methods is helpful as long as the semantics are clearly documented, but the only reason to need equals/hashCode is to use these methods as a key in a map. I just don't think that this makes sense.
Added the explicit methods (and then found myself using them all over the place)

I don't know what you mean by reconcile, and I have no idea how any of the things I could think of could be solved by using the provenance resource.

Hi Grahame - 

Please see the meeting notes from the Reconciliation Discussion at the San Antonio Workgroup meeting. (Tuesday Q1). The recommendation from Lloyd was to use Provenance Resource. If this is not the way to go, should we ask if we can add to the agenda to discuss this at the Patient Care FHIR call this thursday? IHE PCC Volume one finalization is in two weeks. We would need direction from the FHIR Team about the right way to communicate that list or collection of things have been reconciled using FHIR Resouces. You will find the IHE PCC draft profile here. 

 

Thanks, Emma

Reconciliation is the process of taking one or more lists of information (or other list-like resources such as CarePlan or FamilyHistory) and either updating a master list or generating a new list.  Provenance allows you to identify what sources of information were used in deriving the new list/resource version and who was responsible for doing the curation.  So provenance is correct.

To meet Emma's use-case, we need support for reverse include which, though we've talked about it multiple times, is apparently still not there.

PC WG 2/12/15 -- for reconciliation purposes, can point the "list" to other resources.  For example who are the participants in the care plan?  Can point to the care plan, but is that granular enough?  Can do a profile on provenance.reason to faciliatate reconciliation.  Note that "include reverse" (5679).  The reason code indicates that a reconciliation has occurred.   If it were not a reconciliation such as a medication list, what would provenance.reason -- could be used for correction, business event...

Per FMG: 

"ReverseInclude" will enable the ability to retrieve the provenance associated with a resource. Lloyd suggests the following syntax: 

_revinclude=[Resource path that points to this resource]

E.g. Patient?_revinclude=Provenance.target

See tracker 5679 

 

Provenance Resource is used to stipulate why a resource was changed - could be a correction, business reason for a change, reconciliation etc(i.e.why another version of a resource came into being). In the case of reconciliation, provenance will be used to say that reconciliation occurred.

For the situation where care team members or goals or activities are being reconciled, provenance should point to care plan resource and use the reason element in provenance to stipulate what has been reconciled.

How is this different to SampledData? it looks to me like these are really separate observations with different MDC codes, and I don't know why it would be good to create an nested structured for observations inside observations when we already have a proper way to do this

We cannot use dimensioned SampledData due to following reasons:
       - there is no way to name the leads if we don't use extensions,
       - there may occur the time shifts between different leads (for example, ECG recorder records sequentially 3 leads four time to receive 12-lead ECG, see ISO 22077) and different chunks of a lead.

 The idea of SampledDataSet was borrowed from Hl7 aECG schema and example. The fragment from aECG example follows. (SampledData is similar to SLIST_PQ used in this example).


 <!-- Each sequence set stores one ore more simultaneously recorded sequence -->
   <sequenceSet>
      <component>
         <sequence>
            <code code="TIME_ABSOLUTE" codeSystem="2.16.840.1.113883.5.4"
                                 codeSystemName="ActCode"
 displayName="Aboslute Time"/>
 <!-- This sequence is used for the time reference and we will use a
 LIST_TS timestamp -->
    <value xsi:type="GLIST_TS">
    <!-- with a GLIST_TS we provide the head and increment values -->
      <head value="20021122091000.000"/>
      <increment value="0.002" unit="s"/>
    </value>
        </sequence>
    </component>
    <component>
       <sequence>
 <!-- This is the Lead I sequence, we thus give the MDC code for lead I -->
    <code code="MDC_ECG_LEAD_I" codeSystem="2.16.840.1.113883.6.24"
 codeSystemName="MDC"/>
    <value xsi:type="SLIST_PQ">
 <!-- With a SLIST_PQ we need to provide the origin and the scale concepts -->
    <origin value="0" unit="uV"/>
    <scale value="2.5" unit="uV"/>
 <!-- With a SLIST_PQ the values of the sequence are "spelled out" in
 the <digit> element -->
    <digits> -2 -2 -2 -2 -3 -4 -3 -5 -5 -4 -6 -9 -9 -8 -6 -4 -6 -10 -10
So I don't see why this isn't a set of nested observations. They have their own codes, their own times, probably their own reliabilities

Of course this may be represented as a set of nested observations. The question is that ECG data may occur very big and it is preferable to process them as an XML-stream. It is possible for HL7 aECG, it is possible in case of the proposed datatype but I cannot imagine how to implement XML-stream in case of nested observations.

This comes down to an 80% question.  Do most implementers of a particular resource support multiple identifiers?  If so, it should repeat.  If not, it shouldn't and additional identifiers should be conveyed using extensions where they're needed.  However, would be good to have this as official guidance and get WGs to review.

At least in enterprise settings, multiple identifiers are likely in the 80% because there often are a mix of systems.

In our product, we do support and use multiple identifers.  For example, a vaccination records might be manually entered, or transacted in from a pharmacy or medication administration system.  If the the other system sends the EMR a vaccination record, then the original identifiers are stored in addition to ours.  On CDA's we send out both id's.  Similar issues arrise with separate entry points for other objects.

Larry

The point about data types is relevant for integration engine systems.  Often we have people with a variable amount of training working on doing message translations.  Having data type checking on as many fields as possible helps prevent garbage data.

Two days ago I saw a very senior engineer doing something that resulted in data similar to "XYZ.1.2.3" going into an OID field (it was an HL7v2 vs v3 mixup).  Only the data type validating as an OID prevented them from going farther and having to spend time clearing up the issue when a system down the chain gets an error.

I feel like it's better to spend the time ahead with people that really understand something building a spec well- so that the line engineers that use the result of this work can do their jobs with a lesser understanding of the spec.  Having the data types as restrictive as is practicable is an important part of that.  "Oh, I can't put XYZ.1.2.3 in this field?  Ok."

thanks,

Jesse

I don't think that we can make an 80% decision across the entire spec.  It needs to be done on a resource by resource basis.  Having multiple identifiers on Observation is indeed pretty common.  Having multiple identifiers on a MessageHeader is pretty much unheard of.  It needs to be reviewed on a case-by-case basis around what systems actually do.

Variance in pattern is allowed if there are variations in how this information is typically captured for a given type of record.  Do you feel that the way the information is being represented in FHIR diverges from how systems would typically capture it?

In terms of MedicationPrescription and MedicationStatement, MedicationStatement can be written by by clinicians too, often as summaries of current medications.  I.e. you can't assume that medication statements are patient-entered or reported.

For Observation, Observation.performer can be Pracitioner, Organization, Patient or RelatedPerson.  (Make sure you're looking at the continuous integration site before reporting non-technical issues as the resources have continued to evolve since DSTU 1)

Thanks for the quick response.  Perhaps I should reframe the issue in that there are varying degrees of support and patterns for patient entered (and patient reported) clinical data.

I would assume most systems track the "author" of the data.  In the example of a patient portal, then nearly all clinical resources could have data that was patient entered, yet not all resources indicate "who" recorded or supplied the information.  Examples: CarePlan, Goals, Procedures


Of the resources that do support knowing "who", they do so differently.  In some cases, it is a different attribute name.  In some cases, it is a different data type (boolean or link to a resource).  In some cases, it is a different spin on patient-reported data by denoting who is taking responsibility (regardless of who enters or reports it).

AllergyIntolerance.recorder (patient-entered)
Questionnaire.author (patient-entered)
Observation.performer (patient-entered?)

MedicationStatement.informationSource (patient-reported)
Questionnaire.source (patient-reported)
Immunization.reported (patient-reported)

Condition.asserter (who takes responsibility)

In conclusion, when patient entered and patient reported data is added to the mix, it is incredibly important to differentiate this data.  I was expecting that the resources had a consistent approach to handling data veracity/fidelity.

There's no expectation of consistency as a general rule.  Detailed information about exactly who was involved in a record change (data enterer, decision maker, responsible person, device used, information source, etc.) is generally not captured directly on all resource.  What gets exposed and how it gets exposed varies depending on what systems capture and higlight now.  Similarly, the names can vary.based on context.  All that said, we're asking work groups to look at consistency of naming as part of the next release and ensure that variations in naming and approach are indeed being driven by distinct business conventions (not merely because those portions of the specifications may have been authored by different people.)

The Provenance resource provides a mechanism of capturing *all* of these data elements for all resources in a consistent way in those situations where someone wants to go look to understand the full context of a particular version of a record.

If you think that the notion of capturing any of these aspects (author, recorder, reporter, etc.) falls within the 80% (almost all existing systems do it for a given resource type), then please raise specific change requests noting any evidence you have that most existing systems do this for that resource type.  Where most systems *don't* do it, you could request a common extension be defined or you could fall back on provenance.

This would be an example of a 'tag', not a 'security-tag'. Strongly disagree with this.  An encounter represents an event that is "happening".  Mixing "intent" and "event" within the same resource is something we try to avoid unless it matches with business practice.  I'm not aware of any business practice where "proposed" encounters would appear side-by-side with "actual" encounters in the same user interface/persistence layer/etc.

Adding "proposed" as a status for appointment would be more consistent with how this issue is being handled in other spaces.
Lloyd, I here you, but then we need EncounterRequest. It could replace ReferralRequest, since it would subsume it.

But no-one requests "encounters".  They propose, plan or order procedures or diagnostic tests and plan, propose or make referrals or appointments.  Encounters come about as a result of one of those things.  We would only add a new resource if there was a type of request that was used in practice that was distinct from all of those things.  (The fact there's potentially a many-to-many relationship between types of requests and types or resulting activities is just the reality of how healthcare works.)
This comes from QDM and QRDA. For better or worse, they already have the notion of a request or recommendation for follow-up encounter that is neither a referral to someone else, nor an appointment.

But those are abstract models and that's not what FHIR is targeted towards.  When looking at real data, QDM and QRDA would need to look at ReferralRequest and Appointment and ProcedureRequest and DiagnosticOrder to find whether an encounter had been "requested" anyhow.  Adding an additional EncounterRequest resource wouldn't make things better - it would make them worse.  And odds are good that the EncounterRequest resource would never be populated by real systems.  While there is overlap between the use of ReferralRequest, Appointment, ProcedureRequest and DiagnosticOrder, there are lots of clear spaces where only one of those is appropriate and even where there is overlap, there is (or will soon be) guidance about which one(s) should be used in a given circumstance.  It's not clear what guidance could be given for this new resource.

I'm not entirely sure why 'proposed' would be wrong if 'planned' is ok. And I'd like to see a more concrete discussion of why a referralRequest is not adequate and you would need an EncounterRequest instead, because I think it might illuminate the problems with proposed encounters

I did some digging with the help of Chris Moesel. In current US quality measures, Encounter, Order appears only twice. In CMS169, the encounter order is for Outpatient Psychotherapy and so it could be captured as a ReferralRequest. In CMS 111, the time of the Encounter, Order is used as the time of the hospital admit decision in the ER (as distinct from the actual admit time). I think that corresponds to time recorded in the statusHistory of the hospitalization, where Encounter.status=”planned”, so long as the ER visit and hospitalization aren't the same Encounter (they shouldn't be). So I think we are good without further extensions to FHIR to capture QDM in these two existing cases. A recommended followup visit could be captured by a "pending" Appointment. We may want to document that usage. Overall, I think we have this one covered, and the tracker can be closed.
Can you raise a change request to make sure we can capture "proposed" and "planned" for appointment?  Then I'll close this one.

I can imagine situations where the medication might be withheld for permission rules.  In theory, it's possible there could be an administration of an unknown substance.  Both are remote use-cases, but we need to be careful about enforcing constraints that would prevent implementers from saying things that are useful.

The only case I can think of is where a device is emitting observations and it has no knowledge of the subject of the observations. That's definitely in scope.  As a rule, we're extremely cautious about making things 1..1.  If there's any possibility of a system not having the element and still doing something useful, we make minOccurs=0.  Resources don't ever enforce "good practice".  That said, it's reasonable to expect usage notes on elements you would expect to be 1..1 that explain why they're not.

To me, this is evidence of a bigger problem - the scope of procedure is not really well characterised. The content model is not suitable for any particular scope either. If it's only for medical history (as the lack of status suggests) then it's got too much data. If it's for more than that, then it's missing a lot more information (scheduling, preparation information, etc)
Suggest we rename this as ProcedureStatement (to parallel MedicationStatement).  I think that's the primary use-case and represents the sort of data most typically exchanged.
Grahame, what do you think is outside "core" for MedicationStatement?

If we decide to treat Procedure as a retrospective statement (analogous to MedicationStatement), then suitable status values might be: draft | active | superceded | entered-in-error.

If we decide to treat Procedure as an activity (analogous to Encounter or MedicationAdministration), then suitable status values might be: booked | planned | arrived | in-progress | on-hold | stopped | completed | cancelled.  

There might be room for both, of course.

(these are the same values as MedicationStatement)
