A Procedure instance represents something that has happened.  A ProcedureRequest represents something that is desired to happen.  This information is typically captured in different places within systems and user interfaces.  As well, the data elements necessary to capture an order or proposal for a procedure differ from those that are used to capture what actually happened.  Procedure follows the same pattern used in observations (DiagnosticRequest vs. DiagnosticReport/Observation), pharmacy (MedicationPrescription vs. MedicationDispense/MedicationAdministration), etc.  The status of "proposed" doesn't mean that you're proposing an order, it means that the intention of a procedure being done is at the "proposal" stage rather than being a fully authorized "active" order.

>> Procedure follows the same pattern used in observations (DiagnosticRequest vs. DiagnosticReport/ Observation), pharmacy (MedicationPrescription vs. MedicationDispense/ MedicationAdministration), etc. 

No, it doesn't, because Observation, MedicationDispense, MedicationAdministration, all have status attributes but procedure does not:

DiagnosticReport.status = registered | partial | final | corrected | amended | appended |cancelled | entered-in-error

Observation.status = registered | preliminary | final | amended | cancelled | entered-in-error

MedicationDispense.status = in-progress | on-hold | completed | entered-in-error | stopped

MedicationAdminstration.status = in-progress | on-hold | completed | entered-in-error | stopped

PROCEDURE.STATUS = NON-EXISTENT

>>The status of "proposed" doesn't mean that you're proposing an order, it means that the intention of a procedure being done is at the "proposal" stage rather than being a fully authorized "active" order.

I don't know what it means to propose a request. If you look across the other request types, such as DiagnosticOrder, MedicationPrescription, there is no "proposed" status.

Having status on ProcedureRequest is reasonable, though not essential.  That's already been submitted as a separate request.

"proposed" and "planned" are being added as statuses to DiagnosticOrder and MedicationPrescription (and all other "order" resources).  You're not proposing a request.  You're proposing a procedure or diagnostic test or drug administration.

Lloyd, to clarify, there already is a status attribute on ProcedureRequest. There is no status on Procedure.

On your second point, the ProcedureRequest itself IS a proposal for a procedure. You don't need "proposed" and "planned" on requests.

Sorry, you're correct.  Procedure may get a status added, though in practice it's much less commonly used than status on other things.

We do need "proposed" and "planned" on requests so we can differentiate those states from "active" - which means that you have an authorized, actionable order.

If we renamed ProcedureRequest to ProcedureOrder, and similar then I would agree that "proposed" makes sense. It makes sense that an order can be (e.g.) proposed, sent, received, approved, active, and completed, etc...  I just stumble over the notion of a "proposed request".  But "proposed order" is fine.

Well, they're not necessarily proposed orders.  They're proposed procedures or planned procedures or ordered procedures.  It's entirely possible that a planned procedure would be fulfilled by an actual procedure without any order being created (or ever being intended to be created).

My very first comment was, "The problem is that a clinician proposes a procedure, he or she does not propose a ProcedureRequest." You took issue with that. But you now agree??  If you do, then FHIR should not have a "proposed" status on ProcedureRequest, because it implies the ProcedureRequest is proposed.

The ProcedureRequest/ProcedureOrder/whatever we call it can represent a proposal for a procedure, a planned procedure or an active order, a cancelled order for the procedure, etc.  We can add clarity to the name and/or to the description, but it's not appropriate to put "proposed" on Procedure nor to create a separate resource.

I'm sorry, I must not be explaining the issue clearly. The ProcedureRequest (or ProcedureOrder) is defined as "A request for a procedure to be performed." The status is defined as "the status of the order". Therefore, ProcedureRequest.status = "proposed" that means the order is proposed, not the procedure. When the procedure order is "planned" is not a planned procedure, but rather that the order is planned. This is not what we want.

A suitable set of statuses for the order (i.e. the ProcedureRequest) is proposed (e.g. so it can undergo review) | sent | received | accepted | rejected, while a suitable set of statuses for Procedure is planned | in-progress | completed | suspended | aborted.

The only thing I think needs to happen is to change the definition of two status codes:

proposed: "The request has been proposed." to "The procedure has been suggested but no commitment has yet been made"

planned: "The request has been planned." to "The procedure has been agreed to in principle but no formal authorization has yet been initiated"

Then let me ask you a couple of questions: (1) Given your defintion of "proposed" and "planned", would you also define "in-progress" as "The procedure is in progress" and "completed" as "The procedure has been completed"? (2) In what way does "planned" involve obtaining formal authorization for the procedure? (3) What happens to the status value when the formal authorization for the procedure is obtained? (4) After formal authorization is obtained, and subsequently resources are allocated to perform the procedure, but before procedure has been performed, what should be the status of the ProcedureRequest? (5) When the procedure itself is completed, which resource(s) should be updated to reflect this fact?

Mark - perfectly reasonable to propose that a procedure be requested. I don't see why you say that doesn't make sense. it's the kind of thing you'd get back from a decision support system. But the wider issues are indicative of an underlying issue with procedure - it's has no sensible scope, and it's usage other then in medical history is not well explored

>>I don't see why you say that doesn't make sense<<   I am saying you should be able to propose a procedure. However Lloyd has pointed out that the way to do that in FHIR is to propose a ProcedureOrder (currently named ProcedureRequest), rather than to propose the procedure directly. I'm fine with that. Much of the discussion above is about status values. My view is that the ProcedureOrder has some life cycle, e.g.: proposed, sent (aka requested), received, accepted (approved), revised, resubmitted, rejected, etc...  Some time after approval or the order, the Procedure is created, which should also have a life cycle (independent of the order lifecycle), e.g. approved, planned, in-progress, completed, aborted, suspended, etc...   Lloyd has taken the position that status of the Procedure should be incorporated into the status of the ProcedureOrder, and I object to that, based on the fact that the order and the resulting procedure (if any) have separate lifecycles. Furthermore, a Procedure can exist without a ProcedureOrder, so the status of the procedure can't be stored in the ProcedureOrder. Lastly, as you correctly point out, Grahame, without a status, the current Procedure resource seems more like a "ProcedureStatement".

You don't "propose" a ProcedureOrder.  You use the ProcedureRequest resource to represent the proposal for a procedure (or the plan for a procedure or the order for a procedure).  Think of all of them as "ProcedureIntent". 

The status of the Procedure is not incorporated into the ProcedureOrder.  The Procedure resource does act more as a ProcedureStatement - because that's what most EHRs track.  I'd be open to renaming it.

Procedure would never have a status of approved, planned, etc.  It could be "in-progress", "completed" or "aborted", but as a statement, it generally is only relevant to be "completed".

Lloyd, I don't follow your logic. At 2015-02-17 20:54:26 you did seem to say "proposed" and "planned" are valid status values for ProcedureRequest (what I've been interchangeably been calling ProcedureOrder). But you also seem to say that the status of the ProcedureRequest is not the status of the ProcedureRequest. That's nonsensical.

PS - Could you answer me the questions I posed on 2015-02-18 09:00:20? 

PPS - are you sure a procedure could never be "planned"?  That seems to fly in the face of common sense.

If the ProcedureRequest.status says "proposed" that means that the ProcedureRequest currently represents a proposal for the procedure to occur.  If it says "active", that means the ProcedureRequest currently represents an active order for the procedure to occur.  I don't understand what the confusion is.

A Procedure "resource" would never have a status of "planned" because Procedure represents a statement about a procedure that has happened (in theory it could represent a statement about a procedure that's occurring, but it's not clear whether there's a use-case for that or not).  If you want to talk about planned procedures, you use the ProcedureRequest resource - just as when you want to talk about planned drug administrations you use MedicationPrescription, not MedicationAdministration.

Lloyd: "If the ProcedureRequest.status says "proposed" that means that the ProcedureRequest currently represents a proposal for the procedure to occur" -- no. it means that the procedure request represents a proposal to request that a procedure occur. This is a important difference

The status means what the definition says it means.  The proposed new definition says "The procedure has been suggested but no commitment has yet been made".  So that's what the status means - no more, no less.

In my opinion, Lloyd's proposed definitions make no sense. I strongly agree with Grahame. There is no case is FHIR where X.status = Y means anything other than "the status of X is Y". It is that simple. As I said previously, the request for a procedure has a certain life cycle captured in its status: the request may be proposed, sent (aka requested), received, accepted (approved), revised, resubmitted, rejected, etc. This only concerns the procedure request and its disposition. Subsequently, a procedure (for the purposes of discussion, the activity flavor, not the ProcedureStatement flavor) may be created. The procedure has an independent life cycle, whose status may be (for example), booked, planned, in-progress, completed, aborted, suspended, etc. Lloyd, is there something you don't agree with in my description? I have thus far failed to grasp your objections, or even understand what position you are trying to advocate. 

PS - you still haven't answered my questions.

I agree that the "proposed" and "planned" statuses behave a bit differently than the others.  We're mixing moods and statuses here, so that may be throwing you off a bit.  The work groups discussed whether to handle these using a separate attribute or to combine them into status.  The decision was to do the latter because it allowed for more flexible workflow.  "proposed" and "planned" are being added to *all* of the order-ish classes - MedicationProcedure, DiagnosticOrder, ReferralRequest, VisionPrescription and likely Appointment.  So it's not true that "There is no case in FHIR".  FHIR statuses don't always behave the same way as v3 statuses.

ProcedureStatement (which I think more accurately reflects what the resource we have is for) will not have a status of booked, planned, in-progress, etc.  It may be that Procedure itself will, though I'm not sure many (if any) systems capture it with that level of granularity.  I think most of the statuses you've attributed to Procedure will likely end up getting captured only on Encounter rather than Procedure itself.

It's probably best to look at this by examining the Medication resources.  There's MedicationPrescription which can be (or at least will soon be able to be) "proposed", "planned", "active", etc.  Then there's MedicationStatement which can be in-progress or completed and MedicationAdministration which can be in-progress, completed, on-hold or stopped.  There's no notion of "proposed" for any of the "event" resources.  And for Procedure, the notion of "on-hold" probably wouldn't apply either.  (While you can turn off an IV for a while and then turn it back on, procedures typically either complete or get aborted.)

In terms of your questions

(1) Given your defintion of "proposed" and "planned", would you also define "in-progress" as "The procedure is in progress" and "completed" as "The procedure has been completed"?

I don't think "in-progress" makes sense as a Procedure code.  It was copied from Observation where there's value in saying that the lab has started the steps.  I don't think that's typically communicated in the case of procedures.  But if I were to define it, I would say "The requested procedure or set of procedures has been initiated".  And for completed, I'd say "The requested procedure or set of procedures has finished".

(2) In what way does "planned" involve obtaining formal authorization for the procedure?

It doesn't.  Planned is the step before formal authorization.  It just means that there's a commitment/intention to procede.

(3) What happens to the status value when the formal authorization for the procedure is obtained?

It changes to Requested (if done using the same instance), though in some workflows, a separate resource instance will be created to represent the "order".

(4) After formal authorization is obtained, and subsequently resources are allocated to perform the procedure, but before procedure has been performed, what should be the status of the ProcedureRequest?

Could be "Requested", "Received" or "Accepted", though again I'm not sure that those latter two make sense in the Procedure space - copy and paste from Observation again.

(5) When the procedure itself is completed, which resource(s) should be updated to reflect this fact?

Whenever you have an order and that order is fulfilled, both the fulfilling resource (Procedure, MedicationDispense, Observation, whatever) and the order (ProcedureRequest/ReferralRequest, MedicationPrescription, DiagnosticOrder, etc.) generally reflect the "completed" state, though it's possible that it may take multiple fulfilling resources to actually bring the full order to completion.  As well, in some cases (e.g. MedicationPrescription in a community setting), there may not be a closed feedback loop, so the order resource might be updated based on the presumed completion based on elapsed time rather than explicit confirmation that all desired action has occurred.

Thanks for addressing the questions. Please let me explain why I disagree with your proposed defintions. You say planned means "The procedure has been agreed to in principle but no formal authorization has yet been initiated".  According to the dictionary, plan means "to create or design a scheme of action" so planned means "the scheme of action has been created". Whether planning comes before, during, or after formal authorization depends on local workflows. If Joe needs a knee replacement, first the physician proposes it, then Hank's insurance company pre-approves it, then only then does the planning (making the appointment, picking location, allocating resources) commences. So here the pattern is propose, approve, plan, execute.

If Joe is paying out of pocket, the workflow would be physician approval, planning, then execution. As you can see, in both of these use cases, approval does not follow planning, it precedes it.

Nor do I agree with your definition of "proposed" as "the procedure has been suggested but no commitment has yet been made"  The flaw in this definition is that commitment is made only when the procedure is approved. So your definition actually applies to any pre-approval status. "Requested" also is a state where the procedure has been suggested, but no commitment has been made. Ergo, it satisfies your definition of "proposed". Two statuses cannot have the same definition.  

To close on this, I agree that ProcedureRequest itself represents the intent for the procedure to occur. The status tells us how far this intent has moved towards realization. "Proposed" is the first proffering of this intent. "Requested" means the request has been transmitted to the approval authority. "Approved" means that the request has been approved. "Planned" means the request is moving toward concrete realization. QED.

From our perspective, the semantics of "planned" and "proposed" are (and must be) narrower than general use.  The requirements in terms of state machine are "proposed" (whether as a recommendation from a consult or from a decision support engine) to "planned" - captured in a care plan but no formal order yet created to "requested" - formal order created that authorizes action to proceed.  Something being in a care plan doesn't necessarily allow resources to flow, etc.  If you don't like those terms, we can evaluate others, but all of the involved work groups find the chosen terms fairly intuitive.

Not all of those stages will necessarily happen.  You can skip the first two.  You can go directly from "proposed" to "requested".

The "planning" process as you use the word is actually happening through-out the various statuses.  Planning is happening from the moment a proposal is considered through to the point the action is complete.  I can't think of a business trigger that would differentiate between "accepted" and "planned" as you've defined it.

I think what we have here is a failure to communicate. Why don't we use a sequence diagram to help us converge?  I attached my view of the sequence of events as a png file. If you want to edit it, here is a url where you can make changes interactively: http://tinyurl.com/p4jagrh

OK, now we are much closer to convergence. I uploaded another picture (RequestSequence-2.png) based on your input. There is still the problem of "planned" describing two states: one where the details of the request have been filled in, and the other where the task entailed by the request is in the "planned" state. If only could find a way to disambiguate this by finding distinct names for those two states, we could call this issue closed.

I've updated the diagram.  I don't think there is any status change in the order when the filler plans what they're going to do - that's done solely on the filler side - the filler isn't allowed to update the order resource, though they may well create their own.  There is however a "planned" state where the requester agrees that "yes, eggs ought to be bought" but hasn't yet decided when to get them or who is going to get them or even just gotten around to the point where they want to write up the grocery list.

Great, this is definitely progress. We agree on the sequence, and we agree on not reflecting the detailed task status in the request status. Here are the remaining issues:

(1) Task statuses can include "planned", and that is what I originally found confusing. It still is. I propose we call the state where the details of the request have been created "formulated" instead of "planned".

(2) "Refused" and "rejected" are too easy to mix up. That's why I think we should use "proposal-refused" and "request-rejected".  

(3) "Accepted" could refer to acceptance of the proposal or acceptance of the request. Since we are talking about the latter, "request-accepted" is much more clear. 

(3) Also, "fulfilled" is probably a better word than "completed" with respect to a request. (This is minor)

Here's the new sequence diagram URL: http://tinyurl.com/q6lqoql

1. Something like "Encounter" can be "planned", but what that really means is that the event has started from an administrative perspective, but not yet from a functional perspective.  I.e. You've started doing pre-admit labs, the room/equipment have been prepped, etc.  But the patient hasn't showed up for the actual encounter yet.  I don't think you'll be able to sell PA on "formulated", but may be able to get them to improve the definition for the code

2. Typo on my part - both the same status of "Refused".  No differentiation of whether it was rejected as a proposal or an order.  This was discussed with the WGs and they decided they didn't need it.

3. Ditto

4. But that's not the word that's used in business.  Remember, we're not creating an abstract model here, we're using typical business terms.  We're not going to end up with a consistent set of status words used the same across all resources.  The most we'll accomplish is reducing some of the unnecessary diversity we have now.
for Procedure.status, See also 5180

Other clinical resources have similar status codes (AllergyIntolerance). It's not a reuqirement of FHIR methodology that names be consistent across resources, but that they be consistent with the domain language of people who deal with this. Having said that, it's not clear to me that 'status' is an understood term in the domain. (but what else could it be called?)

The notions of things like "accepted" or "completed" don't apply here.  To a certain extent, the transition from provisional to working to confirmed or refuted is equivalent to the transition from pending to active to aborted or completed.  We can confirm with the work group whether they prefer this name or some other, but no reason to change if they don't want to.

This fix handles the case where list is out of order and elements matching the path and found later in the list.

private int processElementsIntoTree(ElementDefinitionHolder edh, int i, List<ElementDefinition> list) {
    String path = edh.getSelf().getPath();
    final String prefix = path + ".";
    while (i < list.size() && list.get(i).getPath().startsWith(prefix)) {
        ElementDefinitionHolder child = new ElementDefinitionHolder(list.get(i));
        edh.getChildren().add(child);
        i = processElementsIntoTree(child, i+1, list);
    }

    // check if any matching elements later in list
    for (int j = i + 1; j < list.size(); ) {
        if(list.get(j).getPath().startsWith(prefix)) {
            ElementDefinitionHolder child = new ElementDefinitionHolder(list.remove(j));
            edh.getChildren().add(child);
            j = processElementsIntoTree(child, j, list);
        } else {
            j++;
        }
    }

    return i;
}

Above fix doesn't work if differential has slicing. Checking for slicing and pre-sorting the list before calling processElementsIntoTree() eliminates the need to further check prefix match beyond the first mismatch.

Reverting to previous processElementsIntoTree() makes sortDifferential() run 2-3x faster.

This proposal is in alignment with the agreement to add "proposed" and "planned" as statuses to MedicationPrescription, DiagnosticOrder, ReferralRequest and other "order-ish" things to allow representation of recommendations from decision support engines as well as inclusion of intended actions in care plans.

I don't believe that we need an additional status added at the start, if you wanted to rename this from pending to proposed I wouldn't object. An appointment is a planning activity, the Encounter is the recording of the actual details.

PA has updated the notes around the Appointment extensively to include the usual status flows and interactions with the other resources in the Notes section.

Just to add some extra detail on the naming, in v2 it is called pending

HL7v2 User-Defined Table 0278 - Filler Status Codes:
Pending | Waitlist | Booked | Started | Complete | Cancelled| Dc | Deleted | Blocked | Overbook | Noshow

So the use-cases we want to meet are:

Recommendation from a decision support system of "patient should be booked in 2 weeks for X".  In this case, no one's committed to it happening - it's just a suggestion.  So "proposed"

Care plan that says "I want to see the patient again in 6 months".  In this case, it's been committed to but there's no real appointment yet - and the record wouldn't have been communicated to an appointment system.  It would be living on the care plan system.  This is what's meant by "planned"

We need both.

Unspecified time appointments are not supported by the current structures.

This functionality we would expect to come from a waitlist functionality, or careplan which can result in creating an appointment which does have a time.

The proposed appointent is a pending appointment. Pending means its waiting for the appointment to be confirmed by the participants (and/or system). For the context of how we've structured appointment, planned/pending are the same concept here, abd leant towards v2 terminology as shown above.

(I would like to know how we can handle wait-listing - not a list resource, unless its a collection of list resources where each person on the list is in a list and sort by those to find them - I think this is a question for the implementers chat...)

I disagree.  "is_a" is clear.  "descendant of" could be based on hierarchy of definition and might include composition relationships, which would be wrong.  I.e. you wouldn't want a "descendant of" relationship between street number and address line.  Changing the name doesn't make any difference in terms of what coding systems you could support.
Why wouldn't you want composition relationships?

Because composition and is_a are distinct things.  You can't use one code for both.  They have different logical properties.  You can do subsumption on is_a.  You can't do subsumption on a "contains".  For example, a street address number is not a kind of street address line and doesn't satisfy a requirement to send a street address line.

The fact that they are separate things doesn't appear to mean that you can't use one code for both in the context of a filter. is there code systems that have both composition and subsumption where you want to differentiate between them?

Sure.  SNOMED has "part of" relationships in addition to "is a" relationships.  MIF defined a set of standard relationship types: Specializes, ComponentOf, GroupedBy, LessThan, DefinitionallyQualifies, NonDefinitionallyQualifies

Of those, Specializes, ComponentOf, GroupedBy and LessThan would be candidates for "standard" filter codes that could be used with code systems that employ those concepts but don't define specific named properties for those types of relationships.  (MIF also defines the inverses of the above, but not sure if there's a use-case for those here.)

Actually, I don't think there is an absolute right or wrong between the choice of descendantOf and is-a in this context, but I think that Lloyd has some good arguments.  If descendantOf is used in a proper subsumption hierarchy, then I think its use is correct and unambiguous.  However, I can think of a different use of "descendant" which is also common and correct and isn't at all what we want here - that would be in the family tree.  In that context, my children and grandchildren are clearly my "descendants", but they certainly are not "subtypes" of me - they are obviously related, but not by is-a. 

So I think that using is-a probably is much clearer about the subsumption behavior that we desire.  But is-a also has a couple of issues of its own.  One is the particular question here, in that it doesn't seem to be obvious to many (most?) whether the "self relationship" is expected to be part of the logical use of is-a, or not.  The other issue is the potential confounding with the SNOMED CT use of "Is a" in its distributed subsumption hierarchy.  In SNOMED CT only some of the logical is-a relationships (the transitive closure) are actually instantiated (via "Is a") - and the "self is-a" relationships explicitly are not instantiated.  So, if you perform a hierarchical query based on the distributed set of SNOMED CT "Is a" relationships, the "head code" will not be included in the result set.

Bottom line, I think that staying with the use of is-a probably makes sense.  But, if we do, we need to say more in its definition than simply "The specified property of the code has an is-a relationship with the provided value" (which is a circular definition, anyway).  We need to be clear that the intended meaning is in the logical sense (not in the SNOMED CT as distributed sense), and we need to be explicitly clear that the "self is-a" relationship is expected to hold.  And the downstream effect of that last point would be that if you want to "intensionally" define a value set based on is-a and you do not want the "head code" to be included in the expansion for some reason then you will need to explicitly exclude it in the value set definition (which shouldn't be much of a problem, as long as you know that you need to do it).
we already have a value set that excludes the head code. So what's a better definition?

The "Using SNOMED CT with FHIR" page (http://hl7-fhir.github.io/snomedct.html) does actually spell out all of the behavior that I mentioned quite clearly.  So maybe we should extract some of the "generic" parts of that explanation and include it in (or link it to) the is-a FilterOperator definition.
well, ok, so the definition: is-a: "Includes all concept ids that have a transitive is-a relationship with the concept Id provided as the value, including the provided concept itself"

Why is it a problem for privacy assessments?  In most systems, family histories are cohesive documents.  You get it all or you get nothing.  Piece-meal control of the individual pieces is rare.  Querying family history and getting back everything but the mother is downright weird.  And the result is going to be that the mother is going to get created multiple times.  This is the same use-case as protecting individual patient addresses or next of kins or steps in a care plan.  It may exist in some very sophisticated environments, but adds a lot of complexity to workflow and processes required to currate records when different participants see different bits.

The initial design (which you checked in May 2013) had 0..* relations and it's always been that way.

Family History isn't recorded as a bunch of independent pieces.  The entire thing gets updated and has a single timestamp and a single author.  It's all considered as a coherent whole.  And you often have notes that apply to the whole history.  A history as narrative would also be the whole history, never the history of a single relative.

Furthermore, even splitting the resource into individual relatives still wouldn't fix the problem, because the privacy issue isn't really the existence of the relative, it's the existence of a particular condition for a particular relative - and we're certainly not going to split that out.

This requirement doesn't fall into the 80%.

It's true that the first commit had this structure, because I redesigned it before it's first commit. 

I don't believe that all your arguments are enough to justify a different approach for FamilyHistory to anything else. Others may wish to comment on the privacy part.

We don't have a different approach for FamilyHistory than anything else.  The scope of FamilyHistory is "What is the granularity with which this information is typically queried and maintained and to which Provenance would be applied within existing systems?"  And the answer to that question is "the entire family history record".  The percentage of times a practitioner would execute a query to retrieve the history of "maternal grandmother" or some other particular relative as opposed to the entire family history record is miniscule.  Similarly miniscule is the percentage of times a person would update an individual relative's record without at least thinking about the entire history.  You don't ask "when was patient's familiy history for Aunt Sue last updated?".  You ask "When was the patient's family history last updated?"

As well, it's often unsafe to update a relative without looking at the family history.  "I just remembered that one of my mom's sisters had emphasema".  "Was that the one who died of breast caner or the other one?"  "The other one".  That conversation can only take place in a context where you can see who all the relatives are.

There will always be security requirements that occur at a level of granularity below the resource.  We can't choose to split resources based on possible security requirements.  We split resources based on the granularity that's manipulated in common practice.  If security requirements have to be applied below that, then they incur that additional complexity.

Now is the time to think through Privacy controls, not just modeling. I see little negative to breaking family history up into component resources to hold each family members data. If you have rights to all of the data you can easily pull the full history and end up with all the data you have. But if a Privacy reason would have some information blocked, then managing this through resources is much easier and more natural for HTTP based access control systems. If we simply breakup the parts, we can use normal HTTP based access controls. If we insist on combining all of the family history into one resource, then we are accepting that we must use complex access controls that must understand the FHIR schema. This is indeed possible, but is unnecessary complexity. The FHIR Principles desire to drive for simple implementations that are Fast and Easy to use.

But privacy isn't at the level of the relative, it's at the level of the relative's condition.  So to truly support the requirement, you'd need to blow out the family history and instead have RelatedPerson be allowed to be the subject of Condition and all the complexity that goes with that.

In talking with the genomics folks at the last WGM (who have the most sensitive family history data), the consensus is that individual controls on access to relative information within a family history record isn't necessary.  FamilyHistory about other relatives is generallly considered "hearsay" and not generally subject to special privacy protections at a granular level.

I'm reluctant to force a change to granularity of the resource that will impact everyone who uses the resource and will make the resource harder to use to accomodate a privacy requirement that is largely theoretical and, to my knowledge, not generally implemented within existing systems.  That seems totally contrary to what the 80% design principle is supposed to guide us towards.

I don't see this usecase as being any more common than the need to provide privacy protections on specific addresses, phone numbers or contacts and we're not considering splitting those out into separate resources.

Entered in error would be weird.  You'd just correct the error - remove the relative, condition, etc.  The "history" of FamilyHistory would show what it looked like at a given point.  Family history is, by definition, always partially unknown.  How much the patient knows about a given relative and how accurate what they report is always somewhat suspect.  So absense of declaration of a condition in a relative doesn't mean they didn't have a condition, only that the reporter didn't know/suspect that they had a condition.  So the question is - do most systems flag whether information about a given relative is more "unknown" than usual?

Entered in error - typically, you just correct things that are correctable. But if you enter on the wrong record, you've got nothing to correct it to, all you can do is delete it. But that's typically considered the wrong thing to do in a distributed clinical record. 

There's a difference between 'my mother lived till old age and was fine as far as I know'  and 'I don't know who my mother is at all, so I don't know her medical history'. (note: this is not an unusual entry in a family history)

I have no idea what existing systems do in this regard, other than it's something you see in text histories.

Have no issue with "entered in error" for the full history record.  But it doesn't make sense for information about an individual relative.

Agree that there will be situations where the health status of a relative may be totally unknown.  It's a question of whether most systems handle that with a discrete element or as part of the notes.

I'd expect a Formulary to be a List resource - the medications in it would be added or removed.  The same Medication instance could appear in multiple formularies.  Not sure if "entered in error" falls in the 80%.
I would not expect a Formulary to be a List resource. I'd expect it to be a Medication end-point doing CRUD on medications. (well, read/search more than create/update/delete).
A hospital system will typically have records for a whole host of medications that aren't "on formulary" - and may actually have multiple "formularies"

We probably need to refactor this to make clear that it's effectively a "ProcedureStatement" - similar to MedicationStatement.  It's not intended to track the detailed execution of the procedure.  Agree with making it clear that it applies to "past" procedures.

Do you have a definition for the code?

Here is the definition from IHE XDS for Folder (direct quote).

"Folder – A Folder is a logical collection of DocumentEntries that are related in some way, such as to a clinical use case. A Folder is an arbitrary grouping relationship. Folders may be updated by multiple SubmissionSets sent from multiples departments that are submitting their DocumentEntry objects at different times. For example, a Folder may be used to collect the DocumentEntry objects for the patient’s documents that relate to an exam event, such as the exam request and prior results as well as the eventual exam results. As the exam results become available, the DocumentEntry objects can be added to the Folder for the exam records."

So some alignment of terms and broading of  concepts

"Folder – A Folder is a logical collection of DocumentReferences that are related in some way, such as to a clinical use case. A Folder is an arbitrary grouping relationship. Folders may be updated by from multiples departments at different times. For example, a Folder may be used to collect the DocumentReference objects for the patient’s documents that relate to an exam event, such as the exam request and prior results as well as the eventual exam results. As the exam results become available, the DocumentReference objects can be added to the Folder for the exam records."

Does the definition need to be specific to DocumentReference?  I'm pretty sure the EHR folks are going to want the concept of "folder" too, but it'll be open to any kind of document reference.  IHE can always constrain the resource type contained by their particular list via a profile.

I provided the XDS definition as the most specific that IHE needs. If the concepts are wider, and yet can be understood in this specific way, then there should be no problem. However too wide of a concept and it won't be understood in the specific way.

How about:

"A Folder is a logical collection of resources that are related in some way, such as to a clinical use case. A Folder is an arbitrary grouping relationship established by the author. Folders may be updated by multiple organizations/departments at different times. For example, a Folder may be used to collect resources that relate to an exam event, such as the exam request and prior results as well as the eventual exam results. As the exam results become available, the resources can be added to the Folder for the exam records.  Folders are concepts in XDS, in EHR extracts and a variety of other data-organization paradigms."
Works great for me.
Recommendation: Add this with definition as proposed above.

We capture status indicating whether the goal was achieved.  Is there a need for more?

Also see #5148

Yes, I think so. The status is all about workflow - eg if the goal is currently active or not whereas the outcome records in more detail what happens when the goal is closed. For example, the goal may have been to lose 10 kg in weight, but only 5 was lost - but still a success (albeit a partial one). Certainly the systems I've developed in the past have recorded outcome  - in response to clinician demand....

I would agree with David on this one, implementing software in other clinical areas we frequently find that the separation of the workflow status of the item and a coded reason it's in that status that's used more for reporting and display to the end user. Even though this is not typically used by the IT system it's still generally worth coding for use in reporting. It's also typically a lot more flexible site by site than the fixed set of status you want for interoperability of IT systems.

The existing status code (and the fact it's a fixed set) provides a good basis for inter-operable systems. But for many of these statuses it's sensible to have an additional coded reason or sub-status.

In my mind this is actually most visible with the canceled status. E.g. it's often useful to report on the difference between:

- Canceled because the patient didn't buy in so was not achievable

- Canceled because the patient has some other condition that makes achievement impractical

- Canceled because the patient has a substantially more sever condition that is being focused on instead

- Canceled because while the goal is not achieved, it's no longer relevant because the strategy for managing the condition has changed

 

While perhaps less clear cut, I agree with David that the same thing applies with achieved goals. Partial vs Full Achievement feels valid. So is "it was on track to achieve but due to a direction of care change is no longer relevant"
